questions.text: Pegloticase is used in the treatment of (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Chronic gout

 

Pegloticase is a recombinant form of uricase, an enzyme that converts uric acid into allantoin, a more water-soluble substance that is easily excreted by the kidneys. Humans naturally lack this enzyme, and pegloticase is specifically designed to address the accumulation of uric acid in patients with gout.

 

Pegloticase is particularly indicated for the treatment of chronic gout in patients who have not responded to conventional therapies. Due to its potential immunogenicity, which can lead to infusion reactions including anaphylaxis, pegloticase is reserved for rare cases of refractory symptomatic chronic gout.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Paralytic ileus: Paralytic ileus is a condition of impaired bowel motility. Pegloticase has no role in the treatment of paralytic ileus.

 

Option C. Psoriatic arthritis: Psoriatic arthritis is an inflammatory arthritis associated with psoriasis. Treatments typically include NSAIDs, DMARDs, and biologics, but not pegloticase.

 

Option D. Rheumatoid arthritis: Rheumatoid arthritis is an autoimmune disorder treated with NSAIDs, corticosteroids, DMARDs, and biologic agents. Pegloticase is not used in the management of rheumatoid arthritis.

 

Educational objective:

 

Pegloticase is used in the treatment of chronic gout, particularly in patients who have not responded to other therapies, due to its ability to lower uric acid levels by converting it to allantoin.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 235

choices.text: Muscarinic M2 receptor
Dopamine D2 receptor
Serotonin 5 HT 1 receptor

questions.text: G-protein coupled receptor that does not act through opening of potassium channels is(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Angiotensin 1 receptor 

 

G-protein coupled receptors (GPCRs) can have various mechanisms of action, including the opening of potassium channels or increasing intracellular calcium levels. Opening potassium channels typically results in hyperpolarization and inhibition, whereas increasing calcium levels generally leads to excitation.

 

  • Muscarinic M2 receptor: This receptor is coupled to G-proteins that open potassium channels, leading to hyperpolarization and inhibition, particularly in cardiac tissue where it slows the heart rate.
  • Dopamine D2 receptor: This receptor is also coupled to G-proteins that open potassium channels, resulting in hyperpolarization and inhibition. It is involved in regulating neurotransmitter release and motor control.
  • Serotonin 5 HT 1 receptor: This receptor acts similarly by opening potassium channels, leading to hyperpolarization and inhibition. It plays a role in mood regulation and other central nervous system functions.

 

Angiotensin 1 receptor: Unlike the others, the Angiotensin 1 receptor does not act through the opening of potassium channels. Instead, it is coupled to G-proteins that activate the phospholipase C pathway, leading to an increase in intracellular calcium levels. This results in vasoconstriction and increased blood pressure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscarinic M2 receptor: This receptor opens potassium channels, leading to hyperpolarization and inhibition, particularly in the heart, where it decreases heart rate.

 

Option B. Dopamine D2 receptor: This receptor also opens potassium channels, resulting in hyperpolarization and inhibition, affecting neurotransmitter release and motor control.

 

Option C. Serotonin 5 HT 1 receptor: This receptor acts through the opening of potassium channels, leading to hyperpolarization and inhibition, influencing mood and other central nervous system activities.

 

Educational Objective:

 

GPCR that acts through opening of K+ channels can result in hyper-polarization, thus leading to inhibition. So, receptor which causes stimulation cannot act through opening of K+ channels.

 

  • Muscarinic M2 receptor, Dopamine D2 receptor and serotonin 5HT1 receptor act through opening of K+ channels.
  • Whereas Angiotensin 1 receptor act by increasing Ca2+.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/56

choices.text: Zidovudine is used as monotherapy for post-exposure prophylaxis
Washing hands with soap and water is advised
Baseline viral markers of health care personnel should be done at the time of prick
Follow up viral markers of health care personnel should be measured at 6 weeks

questions.text: A nurse got accidental prick from the HIV infected needle. Which of the following statements is false regarding the management of this nurse? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Zidovudine is used as monotherapy for post-exposure prophylaxis

 

Post-Exposure Prophylaxis (PEP) involves a series of steps to reduce the risk of HIV infection after potential exposure, such as a needlestick injury.

 

  1. Washing the Wound: Immediately after exposure, the wound should be washed thoroughly with soap and water. This helps to reduce the risk of infection.
  2. Baseline Viral Markers: Blood samples should be taken from the exposed individual to measure baseline viral markers. This provides a reference point to determine if the infection was acquired.
  3. Triple Drug Therapy: PEP should be initiated within 72 hours of exposure, preferably as soon as possible. The recommended regimen includes a combination of three antiretroviral drugs:
    • Tenofovir
    • Lamivudine (or Emtricitabine)
    • A boosted protease inhibitor (such as lopinavir/ritonavir)

 

Zidovudine monotherapy is not recommended. Combination therapy is more effective in preventing seroconversion.

 

  1. Follow-Up Testing: Follow-up viral markers should be measured at 6 weeks post-exposure to check for HIV infection. Additional testing may also be done at 3 months and 6 months.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Washing hands with soap and water is advised: This is correct. Washing the wound with soap and water immediately after exposure is a crucial first step.

 

Option C. Baseline viral markers of health care personnel should be done at the time of prick: This is correct. Establishing baseline viral markers at the time of exposure is essential for monitoring potential seroconversion.

 

Option D. Follow up viral markers of health care personnel should be measured at 6 weeks: This is correct. Follow-up testing at 6 weeks is recommended to detect any early seroconversion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

POST EXPOSURE PROPHYLAXIS

 

  • Treatment should be started within 72 hours of exposure, preferably as early as possible
  • At first the wound is washed with soap and water.
  • Secondly before initiating drug therapy blood samples are taken to measure the baseline viral markers
  • Then, triple drug therapy is given which includes Tenofovir, Lamivudine and a boosted protease inhibitor for 28 days.
  • After 6 weeks again viral markers are measured to check for the infection.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/872

questions.text:
Which of the following is True regarding drugs used for viral infections?

 

  1. Treatment of HCV with ribavirin is considered better than sofosbuvir
  2. Ombitasvir is inhibitor of proteins synthesis
  3. Imiquimod is used for Condyloma acuminata
  4. Simprevir inhibits protease of hepatitis C
  5. Oseltamivir is used for swine flu
questions.solution:
Ans. A. C, D and E

 

C. Imiquimod is used for Condyloma acuminata: This statement is true. Imiquimod is an immunomodulator used for the treatment of various viral warts, including condyloma acuminata (genital warts).

 

D. Simprevir inhibits protease of hepatitis C: This statement is true. Simprevir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HCV, which works by inhibiting the NS3/4A protease enzyme necessary for viral replication.

 

E. Oseltamivir is used for swine flu: This statement is true. Oseltamivir is an antiviral medication effective against influenza A (including H5N1 and H1N1, commonly known as swine flu) and influenza B.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Treatment of HCV with ribavirin is considered better than sofosbuvir: This statement is false. Ribavirin, when used for the treatment of Hepatitis C Virus (HCV), must be combined with injectable interferons, which have significant adverse effects. Sofosbuvir, a newer oral drug that inhibits the NS5B RNA polymerase, is preferred over ribavirin due to its better efficacy and fewer side effects.

 

Option B. Ombitasvir is an inhibitor of protein synthesis: This statement is false. Ombitasvir is an NS5A inhibitor, meaning it acts by inhibiting viral RNA replication and assembly of the hepatitis C virus (HCV), not protein synthesis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sofosbuvir is preferred over ribavirin for HCV treatment due to better efficacy, ombitasvir is an NS5A inhibitor, imiquimod is used for condyloma acuminata, simprevir inhibits HCV protease, and oseltamivir is used for swine flu.

 

 

Reference: KDT 8th/. 853,856,858

questions.text: Drug with mechanism of action are given in two columns. Which of the following is the correct match?(AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1-C, 2-A, 3-B, 4-E

 

The correct matches between the drugs and their mechanisms of action are as follows:

  1. Omalizumab - Anti-IgE (1-C)
    • Indication: Omalizumab is used in the treatment of bronchial asthma. It works by binding to IgE, which plays a key role in allergic reactions.
  2. Itolizumab - Anti-CD 6 (2-A)
    • Indication: Itolizumab is a new drug used for psoriasis. It targets CD6, a molecule involved in T-cell activation.
  3. Daclizumab - Anti-CD 25 (3-B)
    • Indication: Daclizumab acts as an IL-2 receptor antagonist by binding to CD25, which is part of the IL-2 receptor. It is used as an immunosuppressant.
  4. Belimumab - Anti-B lymphocyte stimulator (BlyS) (4-E)
    • Indication: Belimumab is used for the treatment of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). It inhibits B-lymphocyte stimulator, which is involved in the survival of B cells.

 

Educational objective:

questions.text:
Assertion: In a patient admitted in hospital for community acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta lactams and azithromycin is given.

 

Reason: The combination covers gram positive organisms as well as anaerobes.
questions.solution:
Ans. C. A is true and R is false

 

  • In patients admitted in hospital for community acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta lactams and azithromycin is given. Beta lactams covers the gram positive and gram negative organisms whereas azithromycin covers the atypical mycobacteria like mycoplasma and chlamydia.
  • Alternative to this therapy is fluoroquinolones.
  • If a patient is not admitted, then either beta lactams alone or macrolides is prescribed.

 

Educational objective:

 

In hospitalized patients with community-acquired pneumonia, combination therapy of beta-lactams and azithromycin is used to cover typical and atypical bacterial pathogens, not anaerobes.

 

Reference: Katzung 13th/878

questions.text: Drug of choice for treatment of bacterial vaginosis in pregnancy is
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Metronidazole

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for the treatment of bacterial vaginosis, including in pregnancy. Bacterial vaginosis is a common vaginal infection caused by an imbalance of the normal bacterial flora.

 

  • Effectiveness: Metronidazole is highly effective against the anaerobic bacteria that are commonly implicated in bacterial vaginosis.
  • Safety: It is considered safe for use during pregnancy, making it the preferred treatment option.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Clindamycin: Clindamycin is an alternative treatment for bacterial vaginosis and can be used if metronidazole is contraindicated or not tolerated. However, it is not the first-line treatment.

 

Option C. Erythromycin: Erythromycin is not commonly used for bacterial vaginosis. It is more commonly used for infections caused by gram-positive bacteria and atypical pathogens.

 

Option D. Rovamycin: Rovamycin (spiramycin) is a macrolide antibiotic used primarily for the treatment of toxoplasmosis in pregnancy. It is not used for bacterial vaginosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metronidazole is the drug of choice for treating bacterial vaginosis in pregnancy due to its effectiveness against anaerobic bacteria and its safety profile during pregnancy.

 

Rovamycin i.e. spiramycin (which is a macrolide) is drug of choice for toxoplasmosis in pregnancy.

 

Reference: KDT 8th/894-896.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements regarding foscarnet are True?

 

  1. It is used for resistant CMV infections
  2. Renal toxicity is seen
  3. It is activated by viral thymidine kinase
  4. Regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is required
  5. It can cause genital ulceration
questions.solution:
Ans. D. A, B, D and E

 

Foscarnet is an antiviral medication used primarily for the treatment of cytomegalovirus (CMV) and other herpesvirus infections, particularly when the viruses are resistant to other treatments like ganciclovir and acyclovir.

 

Statements:

 

A. It is used for resistant CMV infections

 

This is true. Foscarnet is effective against CMV, including strains that are resistant to ganciclovir.

 

B. Renal toxicity is seen

 

This is true. Renal toxicity is a significant adverse effect of foscarnet, which can lead to acute renal failure and other renal complications.

 

D. Regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is required

 

This is true. Due to its potential to cause electrolyte imbalances, particularly hypocalcemia, regular monitoring of serum electrolytes is necessary during foscarnet therapy.

 

E. It can cause genital ulceration

 

This is true. Genital ulceration is one of the potential side effects of foscarnet.

 

Other Options:

 

Option C. It is activated by viral thymidine kinase: This is false. Foscarnet does not require activation by viral thymidine kinase. Unlike acyclovir and ganciclovir, foscarnet directly inhibits viral DNA polymerase, RNA polymerase, and HIV reverse transcriptase without needing to be phosphorylated by viral enzymes.

 

Educational objective:

 

  • Drug of choice for herpes simplex virus and varicella zoster virus infection is acyclovir.
  • Drug of choice for cytomegalovirus is ganciclovir.
  • Both acyclovir and ganciclovir are pro-drugs and require activation by kinases.

 

FOSCARNET

 

  • It is a simple straight chain phosphonate.
  • It does not require activation by kinases.
  • It is active against H. simplex (including strains resistant to acyclovir), CMV (including ganciclovir-resistant ones) and other herpes group viruses.
  • Oral absorption is poor. Its t½ is 4–8 hours, and it is not metabolized by liver.
  • Toxicity of foscarnet is high. It damages kidney and produces a renal diabetes like condition; acute renal failure can also occur. Anemia, phlebitis, tremors, convulsions, genital ulceration and other neurological as well as constitutional symptoms due to hypocalcemia are frequent.
  • It is administered by i.v. infusion
     

Reference: KDT 8th/852, 853

questions.text: Which of the following is a schedule X-drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Ketamine

 

Schedule X is for the psychotropic drugs i.e. addictive drugs.  

 

Among given options, drug that comes under schedule X is KETAMINE. It is used medically for anesthesia but is also known for its misuse as a recreational drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Thalidomide: Thalidomide is not classified as a Schedule X drug. It is used for specific medical conditions like multiple myeloma and complications of leprosy, but it is not a psychotropic substance.

 

Option B. Colistin: Colistin is an antibiotic used for treating multi-drug-resistant bacterial infections. It is not classified as a Schedule X drug.

 

Option D. Halothane: Halothane is an inhalational anesthetic agent. It is not a Schedule X drug as it does not have psychotropic properties.

 

Educational objective:

 

IMPORTANT DRUG SCHEDULES

 

  • Schedule G: Deals with details of drugs to be labeled 'CAUTION-it is dangerous to take this medicine except under medical supervision'.
  • Schedule H: Deals with drugs and medicine to be sold on prescription-only.
  • Schedule R: Deals with standards for contraceptives.
  • Schedule X: Deals with psychotropic drugs which require special license for manufacturing and sale.

choices.text: TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index
TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects
Both drugs do not need monitoring

questions.text: Which of the following statements is correct for a patient on high dose of penicillin and gentamicin? iNICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index


Therapeutic Drug Monitoring has to be done for drugs that have a narrow safety margin. Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic that acts by inhibiting the protein synthesis at the 30S ribosomal subunit of the bacteria. It is nephrotoxic as well as ototoxic. It has a narrow therapeutic margin; therefore, it requires TDM.

 

Option B. TDM is done with gentamicin because of narrow therapeutic index: Gentamicin is an aminoglycoside antibiotic, and these drugs are known for their narrow therapeutic index. TDM is important for gentamicin to ensure effective therapeutic levels are achieved without causing toxicity. Aminoglycosides can cause nephrotoxicity (kidney damage) and ototoxicity (hearing loss), so monitoring blood levels is crucial to avoid these adverse effects.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. TDM is done with penicillin because of narrow therapeutic index: This is not typically the case. Penicillin, for the most part, does not have a narrow therapeutic index, and Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is generally not required for penicillin.

 

Options C. TDM is done with both because of dangerous side effects: While it's true that both drugs can have side effects, TDM is generally only recommended for gentamicin because of its narrow therapeutic window and potential for serious side effects. Penicillin does not typically require TDM.

 

Options D. Both drugs do not need monitoring: This statement is incorrect because gentamicin does require monitoring due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for toxicity.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Therapeutic Drug Monitoring (TDM) is crucial for gentamicin due to its narrow therapeutic index and potential for nephrotoxicity and ototoxicity. Penicillin, on the other hand, generally does not require TDM because it does not have a narrow therapeutic index.

questions.text: A boy presents with pallor and lymphadenopathy; the X-ray of his skull is given below. Which of the following drug is not used for the management of the suspected diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Vincristine

 

  • The X-ray of the skull is showing circumscribed punched out lesions in the skull of a boy whose history reveals the presence of pallor and lymphadenopathy. This is suggestive of Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis.
  • Langerhans cell histiocytosis (LCH) is a rare disease in which an excess of immature Langerhans cells (a type of white blood cell) accumulates in various parts of the body, leading to tissue damage and dysfunction.
  • The treatment of LCH depends on the severity and extent of the disease, as well as the age and overall health of the patient. Some cases of LCH can go away on their own, while others require treatment.

 

The main treatment options for LCH include:

 

1. Observation: In some cases, particularly in mild cases that only involve one or a few areas of the body, doctors may recommend monitoring the disease closely without any treatment. The goal is to watch for any changes or progression of the disease and intervene if necessary.

 

2. Chemotherapy: Chemotherapy drugs are used to kill the abnormal Langerhans cells and control the disease. Some commonly used chemotherapy drugs for LCH include:

 

  • Vinblastine: Vinblastine is a chemotherapy drug that is often used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children. It works by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells. Vincristine is not recommended for LCH.
  • Methotrexate: Methotrexate is another chemotherapy drug that is commonly used to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.
  • Cladribine: Cladribine is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in more severe cases of LCH that do not respond to other treatments. It works by killing abnormal white blood cells.
  • Etoposide: Etoposide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the ability of abnormal cells to divide and grow.
  • Cyclophosphamide: Cyclophosphamide is a chemotherapy drug that is sometimes used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH. It works by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

1. Steroids: Steroids are often used in conjunction with chemotherapy to help reduce inflammation and improve symptoms.

 

2. Immunotherapy: Immunotherapy is a newer treatment option that involves using drugs that stimulate the immune system to attack and kill the abnormal cells.

 

3. Surgery: In some cases, surgery may be needed to remove damaged or diseased tissue, particularly if it is causing significant problems or pain.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Cyclophosphamide: Explanation: Cyclophosphamide is used in combination with other drugs to treat LCH by interfering with the growth and division of abnormal cells.

 

Options B. Methotrexate: Explanation: Methotrexate is used to treat LCH by interfering with the growth of abnormal cells.

 

Options C. Vinblastine: Explanation: Vinblastine is commonly used as the first-line treatment for LCH, particularly in children, by disrupting the growth of abnormal Langerhans cells.

 

Options D. Vincristine: Explanation: Vincristine is not recommended for LCH. Other chemotherapy drugs like vinblastine are preferred for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Langerhans Cell Histiocytosis (LCH) is treated with various chemotherapy drugs, but vincristine is not typically used for this condition. Vinblastine, methotrexate, cyclophosphamide, and other drugs are preferred for the management of LCH.

ECG monitoring for arrhythmias

questions.text: A patient was treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode in the hospital for 4 weeks. What is the main concern while considering his discharge from the hospital?(INICET NOV 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C.  Suicidal risk

 

The main concern while considering the discharge of a patient who has been treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode is Suicidal Risk.

 

Suicidal risk is a critical concern when discharging patients who have been treated for major depression. The risk of suicide can actually increase as the patient begins to recover, partly because they may gain more energy and motivation before their mood improves significantly. Further TCA are lethal in overdose. Therefore, ensuring that the patient has a safe environment, a follow-up plan, and appropriate support upon discharge is crucial.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Need for Drug Monitoring: While some level of monitoring is advisable when a patient is on imipramine, especially for tricyclic antidepressant (TCA) blood levels in certain cases, it is not typically the primary concern at discharge for depression treatment.

 

Options B. ECG Monitoring for Arrhythmias: Although TCAs like imipramine can have cardiac side effects, including arrhythmias, and may warrant ECG monitoring, particularly in older adults or those with pre-existing heart conditions, it's not usually the primary concern at the point of discharge unless the patient has a known cardiac issue.

 

Options D. Sedation Being the Side Effect: While sedation can be a side effect of imipramine, it is generally not the main concern at discharge. The more pressing issue is the patient's mental health stability and safety.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The main concern when discharging a patient treated with imipramine for a major depressive episode is the risk of suicide. This requires ensuring that the patient has a safe environment, a follow-up plan, and appropriate support to manage their mental health effectively after discharge.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs are used for absence seizures? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

A. Carbamazepine

B. Valproate

C. Ethosuximide

D. Gabapentin
questions.solution:
Ans. B. B and C only

 

The first line drugs for treatment of absence seizures are valproate and ethosuximide. Carbamazepine and phenytoin are contra-indicated in absence seizures.

 

Drugs Used in Absence Seizures

 

  • Ethosuximide: This drug is specific for absence seizures. It works by blocking T-type calcium channels in the thalamus, which are believed to play a role in the generation of absence seizures.
  • Valproic Acid (Valproate): Valproate is effective in treating a wide range of seizure types, including absence seizures. It works by increasing GABA levels and blocking sodium and calcium channels. Valproate is also used for bipolar disorder and migraine prophylaxis.

 

Other Options:

 

Options A. Carbamazepine: Carbamazepine is not used for absence seizures. In fact, it can exacerbate absence seizures. It is typically used for partial seizures and generalized tonic-clonic seizures.

 

Options D. Gabapentin: Gabapentin is not effective for absence seizures. It is mainly used for neuropathic pain and as an adjunctive treatment for partial seizures.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DRUGS USED IN ABSENCE SEIZURES

questions.text: Match the following dilution of adrenaline and its use? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-2 B-1 C-3

 

Dilutions of adrenaline (epinephrine) with their typical uses:

 

  1. 1:1000 dilution of adrenaline is more concentrated and is commonly used in the treatment of Anaphylaxis. It is administered intramuscularly in emergency situations for its rapid vasoconstrictive and bronchodilating effects.
  2. 1:10000 dilution is less concentrated and is typically used in the management of Cardiac Arrest. It's administered intravenously.
  3. 1:100000 dilution is used as an additive in Local Anesthesia. The vasoconstrictive properties of adrenaline help to prolong the action of the local anesthetic and reduce bleeding in the surgical field.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Match the following bacteria with the drug of choice used for each? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A-2, B-1, C-4, D-3

 

  1. Vancomycin is Drug of Choice for Methicillin-Resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) – It acts by inhibiting the cell wall synthesis and is a bactericidal drug.
  2. Metronidazole drug of choice against anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.
  3. Meropenem is used in infections caused by Klebsiella. Klebsiella is known to produce ESBL (Extended Spectrum Beta Lactamases). Carbapenems are not hydrolyzed by ESBL. Therefore, carbapenems like imipenem, meropenem, ertapenem are indicated in the treatment of infections caused by ESBL producing bacteria.
  4. Penicillin like amoxicillin, ampicillin can be used in H. influenzae infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Metronidazole is the drug of choice for anaerobic infections caused by Bacteroides.
  • Vancomycin is the drug of choice for infections caused by MRSA.
  • Penicillins like amoxicillin and ampicillin are used for Haemophilus influenzae infections.
  • Meropenem is used for infections caused by Klebsiella, particularly ESBL-producing strains.

questions.text:
Which of the following drug reduces mortality in COVID-19 patients? (INICET Nov 2020)

A. Dexamethasone

B. Remdesivir

C. Favipiravir
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only A

 

  • In severe COVID-19 infection, there is a systemic inflammatory response, which can lead to lung injury and multiple organ dysfunction. Corticosteroids, due to their anti-inflammatory effect, can help mitigate these negative effects and reduce the mortality in patients.
  • Only dexamethasone has been shown to reduce mortality in severe covid19 cases.
  • Dexamethasone 6 mg IV/PO once daily for 10 days or until hospital discharge is given in severe cases. In the absence of dexamethasone, equivalent doses of other corticosteroids such as prednisone, methylprednisone, or hydrocortisone may be used.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Remdesivir

 

  • Mechanism: Remdesivir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used to reduce the duration of illness in COVID-19 patients, but it has not been conclusively shown to reduce mortality.

 

Option C. Favipiravir

 

  • Mechanism: Favipiravir is an antiviral drug that inhibits viral RNA polymerase.
  • Usage: It is used in some countries for the treatment of COVID-19, but there is no strong evidence to support a reduction in mortality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Dexamethasone is the only drug among the listed options that has been shown to reduce mortality in severe COVID-19 cases, due to its potent anti-inflammatory effects. Remdesivir and favipiravir have not demonstrated a mortality benefit.

questions.text:
Which of the following statements are true? (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Morphine is used for treatment of pulmonary oedema
  2. Pethidine is used for treatment of pain due to biliary colic
  3. Indomethacin can cause headache
  4. Aspirin is used for treatment of peptic ulcer disease
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A and C

 

Aspirin can actually exacerbate peptic ulcer disease due to its mechanism of inhibiting prostaglandin production, which is protective for the gastric mucosa. It is more commonly associated with causing or worsening gastric ulcers rather than treating them.

 

A. Morphine is used for treatment of pulmonary edema: Morphine can be used in the acute management of pulmonary edema, particularly when it's due to heart failure. It reduces preload and afterload on the heart and can alleviate the associated anxiety and discomfort. However, its use has become less common due to concerns about potential side effects, including respiratory depression.

 

C. Indomethacin can cause headache: This is true. While Indomethacin is a non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID) used to treat pain, inflammation, and fever, one of its side effects can be headache.

 

Other options:

 

B. Pethidine is used for treatment of pain due to biliary colic: Pethidine (Meperidine) is generally not recommended for biliary colic because it can cause spasm of the sphincter of Oddi, potentially worsening pain in biliary coli due to its anticholinergic property.

 

D. Aspirin is used for treatment of peptic ulcer disease: This is false. Aspirin can actually exacerbate peptic ulcer disease due to its mechanism of inhibiting prostaglandin production, which protects the gastric mucosa. Aspirin is more commonly associated with causing or worsening gastric ulcers rather than treating them.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Morphine can be used for the treatment of pulmonary edema, and indomethacin can cause headaches.
  • Aspirin is not used for the treatment of peptic ulcer disease and can actually worsen it. While opioids can be used for biliary colic, their use is not without complications, and not all opioids are appropriate for this condition.

choices.text: A, B & C
A, B, C & D

questions.text:
Which of the following is correct about the drugs used in Gout? (INICET Nov 2020)

A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid excretion

B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint

C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways

D. Aspirin is used as it is most powerful NSAID
questions.solution:
Ans. A. A, B & C

 

Options A. Aspirin is not used as it decreases the uric acid excretion: This statement remains correct. Aspirin at low doses can decrease uric acid excretion, potentially worsening gout. Therefore, it is generally not recommended in the management of gout.

 

Options B. Diclofenac is used as it concentrates in the joint: Diclofenac is commonly used in the management of gout due to its anti-inflammatory properties. It gets concentrated in joints and its effect in reducing inflammation and pain in gout is beneficial.

 

Options C. Indomethacin is used as it acts by multiple pathways: Indomethacin is indeed used in the treatment of gout. It is an NSAID that works by inhibiting the production of prostaglandins. It has multiple pathways of action including inhibition of COX and decrease in rate of phagocytosis of urate crystals.

 

Other Options:

 

Options D. Aspirin is used as it is the most powerful NSAID: This statement is incorrect for reasons previously mentioned. Aspirin, particularly at low doses, is not recommended for gout due to its potential to increase serum uric acid levels.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The preferred treatment for an acute gout attack is an NSAID (nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug), such as indomethacin.
  • A typical first-line treatment for gout is indomethacin. Besides suppressing prostaglandin synthesis, indomethacin and other NSAIDs also reduce rate of crystal phagocytosis.
  • Furthermore, intraarticular steroids like methylprednisolone or triamcinolone may be given.
  • Aspirin is not utilized because it promotes renal retention of uric acid.

questions.text:
Which of the following drugs exacerbates myasthenia and is usually avoided in a patient with myasthenia gravis? (INICET Nov 2020)

1. Lidocaine

2. Aspirin

3. Meropenem

4. Phenytoin
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 1 and 4
 

1. Lidocaine can exacerbate myasthenia gravis and should be used with caution in patients with this disease. Lidocaine can cause neuromuscular blockade, which can worsen the muscle weakness and fatigue associated with myasthenia gravis.

 

4. Phenytoin is an antiepileptic drug that can cause neuromuscular blockade, which can exacerbate the muscle weakness and fatigue associated with myasthenia gravis. Therefore, it is generally avoided in patients with this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

2. Aspirin

 

  • Mechanism: Aspirin is an anti-inflammatory and antiplatelet drug. It does not have neuromuscular blocking properties and does not exacerbate myasthenia gravis.
  • Use in Myasthenia Gravis: Aspirin is generally safe for use in myasthenia gravis patients.

 

3. Meropenem

 

  • Mechanism: Meropenem is a broad-spectrum antibiotic. While some antibiotics can interfere with neuromuscular transmission, meropenem is not typically associated with exacerbating myasthenia gravis.
  • Use in Myasthenia Gravis: Meropenem is usually considered safe for use in myasthenia gravis patients.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DRUGS THAT SHOULD BE AVOIDED IN MYSTHENIA GRAVIS

choices.text: Andexanet alfa: Edoxaban
Andexanet alfa: Rivaroxaban
Idarucizumab: Dabigatran

questions.text: Which of the following is not a correct match regarding FDA approved antidotes of anticoagulants? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Ciraparantag: Fondaparinux

 

FDA-approved antidotes for specific anticoagulants are designed to counteract the effects of these drugs in cases of excessive bleeding or when rapid reversal is required for surgery or other urgent medical situations.

 

Ciraparantag is a broad-spectrum antidote that has shown effectiveness against various anticoagulants, including dabigatran, oral factor Xa inhibitors, low molecular weight heparins (LMWH), unfractionated heparin (UFH), and fondaparinux. However, it is important to note that Ciraparantag is not currently FDA-approved for these indications.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Andexanet alfa: Edoxaban: Andexanet alfa is an FDA-approved antidote for oral factor Xa inhibitors, including Edoxaban, Apixaban, and Rivaroxaban. It works by binding to and sequestering the factor Xa inhibitors, thus reversing their anticoagulant effects.

 

Option B. Andexanet alfa: Rivaroxaban: Similarly, Andexanet alfa is also the antidote for Rivaroxaban, a factor Xa inhibitor.

 

Option C. Idarucizumab: Dabigatran: Idarucizumab is a monoclonal antibody that specifically binds to Dabigatran, an oral direct thrombin inhibitor, and neutralizes its anticoagulant effect. This antidote is FDA-approved.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Andexanet alfa is the approved antidote for oral factor Xa inhibitors like Edoxaban and Rivaroxaban, while Idarucizumab is the antidote for Dabigatran. Although Ciraparantag has shown promise as a broad-spectrum antidote, it is not FDA-approved for use with fondaparinux or other anticoagulants.

choices.text: Labile hypertension
Pulmonary hypertension
Treatment of resistant migraine
Resistant Parkinson's disease

questions.text: Inhaled Nitric oxide is approved for treatment of? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Pulmonary hypertension

 

Inhaled Nitric Oxide (NO) has specific clinical applications, particularly in the field of pulmonary medicine. It is approved for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension, especially in certain acute settings. It works by selectively dilating the pulmonary vessels by increasing cyclic guanosine monophosphate (cGMP), thereby reducing pulmonary artery pressure and improving oxygenation. Inhaled nitric oxide is particularly noted for its use in newborns with hypoxic respiratory failure associated with pulmonary hypertension. It can also be used in the acute management of pulmonary hypertension in adults during cardiac surgery or critical care settings.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Labile Hypertension: Inhaled nitric oxide is not used for the treatment of labile hypertension. Hypertension is typically managed with systemic medications rather than inhaled agents.

 

Option C. Treatment of Resistant Migraine: Inhaled nitric oxide is not a standard treatment for migraines, whether typical or resistant. Migraine treatment usually involves a range of other pharmacological interventions.

 

Option D. Resistant Parkinson's Disease: There is no established role for inhaled nitric oxide in the treatment of Parkinson’s disease. Parkinson's disease management primarily involves medications that affect dopamine pathways.

 

Other uses of inhaled Nitric Oxide:

 

  • Neonatal Care: It is particularly valuable in the treatment of newborns with persistent pulmonary hypertension of the newborn (PPHN) to improve oxygenation.
  • Acute Respiratory Distress Syndrome (ARDS): While its benefits in ARDS in adults are still a subject of research and debate, it has been used for its pulmonary vasodilator effects in some critical care settings.
  • Cardiac Surgery: Inhaled NO can be used during cardiac surgery to control pulmonary artery pressures.
  • Lung Transplantation: It may be used to reduce pulmonary hypertension and improve graft function immediately after transplantation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Inhaled Nitric Oxide is approved for the treatment of pulmonary hypertension, particularly in acute settings to reduce pulmonary artery pressure and improve oxygenation. It is not used for labile hypertension, migraines, or Parkinson's disease.

choices.text: Pleuropulmonary blastoma

questions.text: Nivolumab is used as a checkpoint inhibitor in?
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Hodgkin's lymphoma

 

Nivolumab is a monoclonal antibody that works as an immune checkpoint inhibitor by blocking the interaction between PD-1 on the surface of T cell and its ligand present on the tumor cell. It is used in the treatment of Non-small cell lung cancer, Hodgkin’s Lymphoma, Advanced melanoma and advanced head and neck cancer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Retinoblastoma: Nivolumab is not typically used for the treatment of retinoblastoma, which is a rare type of eye cancer that usually develops in early childhood.

 

Option B. Medulloblastoma: This is a type of brain cancer more common in children. Nivolumab is not a standard treatment for medulloblastoma.

 

Option C. Pleuropulmonary blastoma: This is a rare type of cancer that starts in the lung or pleural cavity, mostly affecting children. Nivolumab is not indicated for this cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nivolumab is an immune checkpoint inhibitor used for the treatment of Hodgkin’s lymphoma, among other cancers such as non-small cell lung cancer, advanced melanoma, and advanced head and neck cancer. It works by blocking the PD-1/PD-L1 interaction, thereby enhancing the immune response against cancer cells.

 

Immune check point inhibitors

 

New:                Nivolumab

Drugs:              Durvalumab

Act:                  Avelumab

At:                   Atezolizumab

Immune:          Ipilimumab

Check:             Cemiplimab

Point:               Pembrolizumab

choices.text: Presence of benzalkonium bromide in the preparation
Associated use of hypertonic saline in nebulizer

questions.text: All of the following can be the mechanism for paradoxical bronchoconstriction seen with the use of ipratropium bromide Except? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prejunctional M2 receptor stimulation

 

Pre-synaptic muscarinic M2 receptors inhibit the release of acetylcholine which is a potent bronchoconstrictor. Therefore, presynaptic stimulation of these receptors will result in bronchodilation, not constriction. On the other hand, ipratropium can cause transient bronchoconstriction initially, one the reason is blockade (not stimulation) of the pre-synaptic receptors resulting in more release of acetylcholine.

 

  • Paradoxical bronchoconstriction with ipratropium bromide, particularly when given by nebulizer, were largely explained as:

    • Effects of the hypertonic nebulizer solution

    • Antibacterial additives, such as benzalkonium chloride and EDTA.

    • Presynaptic blockade (not stimulation) of muscarinic (M2) receptors

  • This problem has not been described with tiotropium bromide or other LAMAs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Presence of benzalkonium bromide in the preparation: Benzalkonium bromide is a preservative that can cause bronchoconstriction in susceptible individuals when used in nebulized medications.

 

Option C. Associated use of hypertonic saline in nebuliser: Hypertonic saline can irritate the airways and lead to bronchoconstriction, which can explain paradoxical reactions during nebulization.

 

Option D. Presence of EDTA as impurity: EDTA, used as a stabilizing agent in some formulations, can also cause bronchoconstriction by irritating the airways

 

Educational Objective:

 

Paradoxical bronchoconstriction associated with ipratropium bromide is not caused by prejunctional M2 receptor stimulation. Instead, it can be caused by the presence of benzalkonium bromide, use of hypertonic saline, and presence of EDTA as impurities, which can all irritate the airways and lead to bronchoconstriction.

choices.text: Intra-abdominal infections

questions.text: Antimicrobial combinations are used in all except? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Gonorrhea

 

Drug of choice for treatment of gonorrhea is single dose ceftriaxone therapy. It does not require combination therapy.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. For Management of Tuberculosis, a combination of drugs consisting of Rifampicin, Isoniazid, Pyrazinamide and Ethambutol are used. In cases like MDR or XDR TB, other drugs like Bedaquiline, Levofloxacin, Ethionamide etc. are used in various combinations and in the form of different regimens.

 

Option C. Intraabdominal infections are generally polymicrobial in nature consisting of both aerobic and anaerobic microorganisms. Combination therapy with metronidazole and other agents like ciprofloxacin, cefepime, etc. are used as empirical agents to treat them.

 

Option D. Malaria: In case of Plasmodium vivax infection, Chloroquine is used for 3 days + Primaquine is added for 14 days. For P. Falciparum infection, combination therapy consisting of ACT-SP (Artesunate + Sulfadoxine + Pyrimethamine) are used along with a single dose of Primaquine on Day 2. For P. Falciparum infection in the north eastern states, ACT-AL (Artemether + Lumefantrine) is used.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Antimicrobial combination therapy is not used for the treatment of gonorrhea, which is typically managed with single-dose ceftriaxone therapy. In contrast, tuberculosis, intra-abdominal infections, and malaria require combination therapy to effectively manage the infections and prevent resistance.

questions.text: Which of the following is the site of action of vancomycin as shown in  the image below
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Vancomycin is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor. It binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking by inhibiting transglycolase. Therefore, in the above given image, it acts at the step 4. Vancomycin is a bactericidal agent used against gram positive bacteria.
 

Other options:


Option A. 1: Fosfomycin inhibits step 1 in the image. It inhibits the cytoplasmic enzyme enol pyruvate transferase that catalyses the initial step in the bacterial cell wall synthesis. It is used for the treatment of urinary tract infections.

 

Option B. 2: It is inhibited by Cycloserine. It is a structural analog of D-alanine and inhibits the enzymes alanine racemase that converts L-alanine to D-alanine and d-alanyl-d-alanine ligase, thereby preventing the incorporation of D-alanine into the peptidoglycan chain.

 

Option C. 3: Bacitracin inhibits step 3 in the image. It is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor that interferes with dephosphorylation of the BP transporter which transfers peptidoglycan subunits to the growing cell wall.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vancomycin acts at step 4 in the bacterial cell wall synthesis process by binding to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of peptidoglycan precursors, thereby inhibiting further elongation and cross-linking of the peptidoglycan.

choices.text: Half-life doubles and plasma concentration remains the same
Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles
Half-life and plasma concentration remains the same
Half-life and plasma concentration doubles

questions.text: What would happen to the half-life and plasma concentration of a drug which follows first-order kinetics, if the dose is doubled? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Half-life remains the same and plasma concentration doubles
 

In case of drugs following 1st order kinetics, a constant fraction of the drug is eliminated in a given time. Therefore, the half-life of the drug remains constant and the Clearance also remains constant.

 

Key points regarding first-order kinetics:

 

  • Half-life remains constant: The half-life of the drug does not change with the dose. It remains constant because the fraction of the drug eliminated per unit time is constant.
  • Clearance remains constant: The clearance, which is the volume of plasma from which the drug is completely removed per unit time, remains constant.
  • Plasma concentration: When the dose is doubled, the plasma concentration of the drug also doubles because the rate of elimination is proportional to the concentration of the drug in the plasma.

 

Educational Objective:

 

For drugs following first-order kinetics, The rate of elimination of the drug is directly proportional its plasma concentration. So, when the dose is doubled for a drug following first order kinetics, the plasma concentration is also doubled.

choices.text: Bipolar disorder

questions.text: Which of the following is not an off-label use of risperidone? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bipolar disorder
 

Off-label drug use refers to the prescription of a medication for a condition that is not included in its approved labeling by the Food and Drug Administration (FDA).

 

Risperidone is FDA-approved for the treatment of bipolar disorder. It is specifically approved for the short-term treatment of acute manic or mixed episodes associated with Bipolar I Disorder, both as monotherapy and as an adjunct to lithium or valproate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. OCD (Obsessive-Compulsive Disorder): The use of risperidone for OCD is generally considered off-label. While antipsychotics like risperidone can be used adjunctively in treatment-resistant OCD, it's not an FDA-approved indication.

 

Option B. Dementia: Using risperidone for the treatment of behavioral symptoms in dementia is off-label. Although it's sometimes prescribed for this purpose, it's important to note that the FDA has issued a black box warning about the increased risk of death when using antipsychotic drugs in elderly patients with dementia-related psychosis.

 

Option C. PTSD: (Post-Traumatic Stress Disorder): The use of risperidone in PTSD is also off-label. It has been studied and used for managing certain symptoms of PTSD, but it is not an FDA-approved indication for this condition.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Risperidone is FDA-approved for the treatment of bipolar disorder, making it a labeled use. In contrast, the use of risperidone for OCD, dementia, and PTSD are off-label indications.

choices.text: 20.8 hours
6.9 hours
13.8 hours

questions.text: The elimination rate constant of a drug is 0.05 hr. What is its half-life? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 13.8 hours

 

  • Half-life is the time in which the plasma concentration of the drug becomes half.
  • The elimination rate constant of a drug reflects the fraction of drug that is removed from the body compartment per unit time.
  • The elimination rate constant = k = 0.05 hr.
  • Half-life = t1/2 = 0.693/k
  • Therefore t1/2 = 0.693/0.05 =13.8 hrs.
     

Educational Objective:

 

The half-life of a drug with an elimination rate constant of 0.05 hr is 13.8 hours, calculated using the formula t1/2=0.693/k

choices.text: 30 minutes
60 minutes
90 minutes

questions.text: A patient is on phenytoin for a seizure disorder. He was prescribed sucralfate 4 times a day for peptic ulcers. What should be the minimum duration of time between consumption of these drugs? (INICET May 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 120 minutes

 

  • Sucralfate is made up of aluminium octosulphate of sucrose. In the acidic pH of the stomach, it gets polymerized into a viscous fluid which adheres to the base of the ulcer for upto 6 hours. However, this viscous layer prevents the absorption of other drugs like phenytoin, ketoconazole, fluoroquinolones etc. from the stomach.
  • When a patient is taking both phenytoin (an antiepileptic drug) and sucralfate (a medication used to treat peptic ulcers), it's important to manage the timing of these medications to avoid drug interactions.
  • Sucralfate can interfere with the absorption of phenytoin when taken too closely together, leading to reduced effectiveness of phenytoin.
  • The general recommendation is to separate the administration of these two drugs by at least 2 hours. This separation allows sufficient time for the phenytoin to be absorbed before the sucralfate is taken, which can bind to drugs in the gastrointestinal tract and hinder their absorption.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The minimum duration of time between the consumption of phenytoin and sucralfate should be at least 120 minutes (2 hours) to ensure that phenytoin is adequately absorbed and to avoid interactions that could reduce its effectiveness.

questions.text: A young boy with a history of multiple blood transfusions presents with bone pain for the past 6 months. A peripheral smear showed sickle-shaped RBCs. Which of the following drugs are not used in the treatment of his condition? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Bebtelovimab

 

  • The given clinical features are suggestive of Sickle cell anemia. Voxelotor, hydroxyurea and L-glutamine are used for treatment of sickle cell anemia whereas Bebtelovimab is not used in in this condition.
  • Bebtelovimab is a new monoclonal antibody used for the treatment of COVID-19. It works by binding to the spike protein of the COVID-19 virus.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Voxelotor: Is an inhibitor of hemoglobin S polymerase and stabilizer of sickle cell hemoglobin (HbS) that is used in the therapy of sickle cell disease.

 

Option C. Hydroxyurea: Improves fetal hemoglobin (HbF) and is the primary drug for controlling HbS in sickle cell disease. Thus, improving the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood.

 

Option D. L-glutamine: Is a naturally occurring amino acid with antioxidant properties. It increases the availability of reduced glutathione which may lessen oxidative damage in sickle red blood cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bebtelovimab is not used in the treatment of sickle cell anemia; it is a monoclonal antibody used for COVID-19 treatment. In contrast, Voxelotor, Hydroxyurea, and L-glutamine are used in managing sickle cell anemia by improving hemoglobin function and reducing oxidative stress in red blood cells.

choices.text: 48 hours
70 hours
90 hours
120 hours

questions.text: The half-life of letrozole is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. 48 hours

 

  • The half-life of letrozole is 48 hours.
  • Letrozole is an aromatase inhibitor which is used in the treatment of ER +ve breast cancers in post-menopausal women.
  • It is also the DOC for treating infertility due to anovulation in PCOS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The half-life of letrozole is 48 hours. It is an aromatase inhibitor used in the treatment of ER+ breast cancer in post-menopausal women and as the drug of choice for treating infertility due to anovulation in women with PCOS.

questions.text: The given diagram shows the steps in bacterial cell wall formation. Identify the site of action of beta-lactam antibiotics. (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. 4

 

Beta lactams act on step 4 in the given image.

 

The beta lactams inhibit the formation of bacterial cell wall by inhibiting the Transpeptidase enzyme which is required for the cross linking of the peptidoglycan chains; therefore, they lead to a reduction in the strength of the bacterial cell wall which ultimately causes it to burst, leading to the death of the bacteria.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1: Fosfomycin inhibits step 1 in the image. It inhibits the cytoplasmic enzyme enol pyruvate transferase that catalyses the initial step in the bacterial cell wall synthesis. It is used for the treatment of urinary tract infections.

 

Option B. 2: Bacitracin inhibits step 2 in the image. It is a cell wall synthesis inhibitor that interferes with dephosphorylation of the BP transporter which transfers peptidoglycan subunits to the growing cell wall.

 

Option C. 3: Vancomycin inhibits step 3 in the image. It binds to the D-Ala-D-Ala terminus of the newly formed peptidoglycan pentapeptide. This prevents further elongation of the peptidoglycan and its cross-linking by inhibiting transglycolase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Beta-lactam antibiotics act at step 4 in the bacterial cell wall synthesis process by inhibiting transpeptidase enzymes, which are essential for cross-linking peptidoglycan chains, thereby weakening the bacterial cell wall and causing cell lysis.

questions.text: Phospholipase C acts via which of the following G protein-coupled receptors?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Gq 

 

Phospholipase C acts via the Gq type of G protein-coupled receptors. It leads to the activation of the IP3-DAG pathway. The receptors that act via this pathway include the receptors of H1, α1, M1, V1, M3, Angiotensin II, Gastrin, GnRH, Oxytocin and TRH.


Important points about GPCR:

 

G protein-coupled receptors (GPCRs) are cell membrane receptors that span across the membrane 7 times (heptahelical). Subtypes of GPCRs are distinguished by their alpha subunits. The important subtypes of GPCRs are Gs, Gp, Gq, and Go. GPCRs act via various second messengers. The important ones with their action on the effector are:

 

  • Gs causes activation of adenylyl cyclase and thus increase in cAMP.
  • Gi causes inhibition of adenylyl cyclase and thus decrease in cAMP.
  • Go causes Ca2+ channel inhibition.
  • Gq causes activation of phospholipase C which generates the second messengers inositol trisphosphate (IP3) and diacylglycerol (DAG). It helps in mobilizing Ca2+ form the endoplasmic reticulum stores.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Phospholipase C (PLC) is activated by Gq-coupled receptors, which in turn generate the second messengers IP3 and DAG, leading to various downstream effects, including the mobilization of calcium ions from intracellular stores.

questions.text: A patient was diagnosed with pulmonary tuberculosis and was started on first-line antitubercular drugs. Which of the following drug acts by inhibiting the synthesis of the marked layer shown by arrow in the image?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Isoniazid

 

Isoniazid is activated by Catalase Peroxidase and it acts by blocking the mycolic acid synthesis. It is a bactericidal drug that is effective against both intracellular and extracellular bacteria that are actively replicating.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Rifampicin: It is the most bactericidal drug, that is effective against intra as well as extracellular bacteria. It acts by blocking RNA polymerase.


Option C. Pyrazinamide: It is also bactericidal, that is effective mainly against intracellular bacteria. It acts by blocking fatty acid synthase.


Option D. Ethambutol: It is a bacteriostatic 1st line anti-tubercular drug that acts against both intra and extracellular bacteria by blocking arabinosyl transferase.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Isoniazid acts by inhibiting the synthesis of mycolic acid, a critical component of the mycobacterial cell wall, making it an effective first-line treatment for tuberculosis. The other first-line drugs have different mechanisms of action, such as inhibiting RNA polymerase (rifampicin), blocking fatty acid synthase (pyrazinamide), and inhibiting arabinosyl transferase (ethambutol).

choices.text: Muscle fasciculations

questions.text: A man was brought to the emergency room after poisoning with an unknown substance. Muscarinic poisoning was suspected and he was treated for the same. What is the possible presenting feature which led to the diagnosis?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Bradycardia
 

The types of Muscarinic receptors and their actions are as follows:

 

  • M1 – They increase the acid secretion in the stomach
  • M2 – They are present in the heart and lead to a decrease in heart rate (Bradycardia) and cause slowing of conduction in the AV node.
  • M3 – They are present in the respiratory tract and cause bronchoconstriction. They are also present in the urinary bladder, where they help in urination by bringing about contraction of the bladder. In the glands, these receptors help in secretion. In the eyes it leads to miosis.

 

Bradycardia is the possible presenting feature which led to the diagnosis of muscarinic poisoning in this case. Muscarinic poisoning occurs due to the consumption of poisonous mushroom-like Inocybe. Muscarinic symptoms appear within an hour of eating the mushroom. These symptoms (along with nicotinic symptoms) can also be seen in organophosphate poisoning. Atropine is used for the management of muscarinic poisoning.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Mydriasis: This refers to pupil dilation, which is typically associated with sympathetic stimulation or anticholinergic effects, not muscarinic poisoning.

 

Option B. Diuresis: This refers to increased urine production, which is not a direct effect of muscarinic poisoning. Muscarinic activation actually increases bladder contraction, promoting urination.

 

Option C. Muscle fasciculations: These are more associated with nicotinic receptor activation, not muscarinic receptor activation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bradycardia is a key presenting feature that can lead to the diagnosis of muscarinic poisoning. Muscarinic receptors, particularly M2 receptors in the heart, mediate a decrease in heart rate. Atropine is used to manage muscarinic poisoning by blocking acetylcholine's action on these receptors.

questions.text: A 29-year-old lady came to psychiatry OPD with symptoms of hypomania. There is a past history of maniac episode. Now, she is planning to conceive. Which of the following drug is maximum teratogenic to the fetus?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Valproate

 

  • Valproate is the most teratogenic drug among the drugs used in bipolar disorder and anti-epileptic medications. It causes congenital anomalies like neural tube defects (spina bifida), cleft lip and cleft palate, and cardiac anomalies. It also contributes to poor cognitive development in children.
  • Although lithium is also teratogenic and can cause Ebstein anomaly in the fetus, but it is less teratogenic than valproate.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lamotrigine: This medication is also used to treat bipolar disorder and epilepsy, but it has a lower risk of teratogenic effects compared to valproate. The risk of major congenital malformations with lamotrigine is relatively low.

 

Option C. Oxcarbazepine: Used to treat epilepsy and bipolar disorder, oxcarbazepine has a moderate risk of teratogenic effects, but it is still considered less teratogenic than valproate.

 

Option D. Olanzapine: This antipsychotic medication is used for bipolar disorder and schizophrenia. While there are some risks associated with its use during pregnancy, including potential metabolic complications, it is not considered as teratogenic as valproate.

 

Additional Note on Lithium

 

Although lithium is also used to treat bipolar disorder and is known to be teratogenic, causing conditions like Ebstein's anomaly (a heart defect), its teratogenic risk is considered lower than that of valproate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Valproate is the most teratogenic drug among the options listed, causing significant congenital anomalies such as neural tube defects, cleft lip and palate, and cardiac anomalies, as well as poor cognitive development. It should be avoided in women who are planning to conceive or are pregnant.

questions.text:
True statement regarding the administration of 5 alpha-reductase inhibitors is/are: (INICET MAY 2022)

 

1. Reduces dihydrotestosterone levels

 

2. Reduces testosterone levels

 

3. Elevates PSA levels

 

4. Decreases PSA levels
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1, 4

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors, such as finasteride and dutasteride, are used primarily in the treatment of benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH) and conditions like male pattern baldness and hirsutism. These medications work by inhibiting the enzyme 5 alpha-reductase, which is responsible for converting testosterone into dihydrotestosterone (DHT), a more potent androgen.

 

Effects of 5 Alpha-Reductase Inhibitors

 

  1. Reduces Dihydrotestosterone Levels: By inhibiting the conversion of testosterone to DHT, these drugs significantly lower DHT levels in the body. DHT is a key factor in the development and enlargement of the prostate and also contributes to hair loss.
  1. Decreases PSA Levels: Prostate-specific antigen (PSA) levels are often reduced as a result of decreased prostate volume and reduced androgenic stimulation of the prostate. PSA is a marker used to screen for and monitor prostate cancer and other prostate-related conditions.

 

Other Options:

 

  1. Reduces Testosterone Levels: This statement is incorrect. 5 alpha-reductase inhibitors do not significantly reduce testosterone levels. In fact, due to the reduced conversion to DHT, plasma testosterone levels may remain unchanged or even increase slightly.
  2. Elevates PSA Levels: This statement is incorrect. These drugs typically decrease PSA levels due to reduced androgenic activity in the prostate.

 

Additional Information

 

  • Uses: These inhibitors are used alongside surgery and alpha-1 adrenergic blockers for treating BPH. They are also utilized in managing male pattern baldness and hirsutism.
  • Mechanism of Action: By competitively inhibiting 5 alpha-reductase, they reduce the production of DHT, which is responsible for stimulating prostate growth and hair loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

5 alpha-reductase inhibitors are the competitive inhibitors of the enzyme 5 alpha-reductase which converts testosterone into the more active dihydroxy testosterone (DHT). This enzyme inhibition results in:

 

 

  • Decreased DHT levels
  • Decreased PSA levels
  • Reduces prostate volume
  • However, plasma testosterone levels remain unchanged or may increase due to non-conversion to DHT.

choices.text: Spurious drug
Adulterated drug
Unethical drug
Misbranded drug

questions.text: The manufacturer of a drug company labels a drug as having 500 mg paracetamol. On quantitative analysis of the drug, it actually contained only 200 mg of paracetamol. What is this type of drug called? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Misbranded drug

 

A misbranded drug refers to a drug whose labeling is inaccurate or misleading. This includes incorrect labeling of the quantity of active ingredients. In this scenario, where the medication is labeled as containing 500 mg of paracetamol but actually contains only 200 mg, it would be considered a misbranded drug.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Spurious drugs: These products are manufactured concealing the true identity of the product and made to resemble another drug, especially some popular brand, to deceive the buyer and cash on the popularity of original product. The product may or may not contain the active ingredients. Spurious drugs are usually manufactured by unlicensed anti-social elements but sometimes licensed manufacturers may also be involved.

 

Option B. Adulterated drugs: These are those drugs which are found to contain an adulterant/substituted product or contaminated with filth rendering it injurious to health

 

Option C. Unethical drug: "Unethical drug" is not a standard term in pharmaceutical regulation. The issue here is not primarily about ethics but rather about the accuracy of labeling and drug quality.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A drug labeled inaccurately with respect to its active ingredient quantity is considered a misbranded drug. Ensuring accurate labeling is crucial for regulatory compliance and consumer safety, as it ensures that drugs on the market are labeled truthfully and can be trusted for their intended use.

questions.text: Which of the following anti-diabetic drugs is associated with the increased risk of fractures? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Rosiglitazone

 

Rosiglitazone, a drug belonging to the class of thiazolidinediones, has been associated with an increased risk of bone fractures. The mechanism behind this is not fully understood, but it is thought that thiazolidinediones might interfere with bone metabolism (PPARγ agonist), leading to decreased bone mineral density which can increase the risk of fractures, especially in postmenopausal women.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Liraglutide: It is a GLP-1 receptor agonist used in the treatment of type 2 diabetes. There is no strong evidence linking liraglutide to an increased risk of fractures.

 

Option C. Voglibose: It is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor which delays the absorption of carbohydrates from the intestines. It has not been primarily associated with an increased risk of fractures.

 

Option D. Canagliflozin: It is one of the SGLT2 inhibitors that works by removing glucose through the urine. While there have been some discussions about bone density changes with SGLT2 inhibitors, canagliflozin specifically has had mixed results in studies regarding fracture risk.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Glitazones like rosiglitazone and pioglitazone are associated with following adverse effects:

 

  • Hepatotoxicity
  • Retention of sodium and water
  • Risk of osteoporotic fractures

 

SGLT-2 inhibitors like canagliflozin is also associated with increased risk of fractures but the incidence is much lower than that with glitazones.

choices.text: N - hydroxy cyclophosphamide
4 - hydroxy cyclophosphamide
4 - acetyl cyclophosphamide
N - acetyl cyclophosphamide

questions.text: The active metabolite of cyclophosphamide is: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 4 - hydroxy cyclophosphamide

 

  • Cyclophosphamide is an alkylating chemotherapeutic agent whose active metabolite is 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide.
  • Side Effects:
    • Hemorrhagic Cystitis: One of the most notable side effects of cyclophosphamide is hemorrhagic cystitis. This is due to the accumulation of the metabolite acrolein in the bladder. To prevent this, mesna (a uroprotective agent) is administered alongside cyclophosphamide, and patients are advised to maintain adequate hydration.
    • Pulmonary Fibrosis: Another significant side effect is pulmonary fibrosis, which can affect lung function.
    • Bone Marrow Suppression: Like many chemotherapeutic agents, cyclophosphamide can also cause bone marrow suppression, leading to leukopenia, anemia, and thrombocytopenia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cyclophosphamide's therapeutic effects are primarily due to its active metabolite, 4-hydroxy cyclophosphamide. It is important to manage the side effects of cyclophosphamide, particularly hemorrhagic cystitis, through the use of mesna and adequate hydration. Pulmonary fibrosis and bone marrow suppression are other significant side effects to be monitored during treatment.

choices.text: A, B, D
A, C, D
A and C
A and D

questions.text:
Choose the correct options regarding the route of administration and bioavailability:  (INICET MAY 2022)

 

A - Intravenous = 1

B - 0.75 < Oral <1

C - 0.75 < IM (Intramuscular) <1

D - 0.75 < SC (Subcutaneous) <1
questions.solution:
Ans. B. A, C, D

 

To evaluate these options, we need to understand the route of administration and bioavailability for each:

 

  1. Intravenous (IV): The bioavailability of a drug administered intravenously is always 1 (or 100%) because it directly enters the systemic circulation without any barriers to absorption.
  2. Oral: The bioavailability of oral medications is typically less than 1 (or 100%) because of the first-pass metabolism (metabolic degradation of a drug before it reaches systemic circulation) and variable absorption in the gastrointestinal tract.
  3. Intramuscular (IM): The bioavailability of IM administered drugs is typically high but usually less than 1 due to factors like local blood flow and muscle type. It is often close to 1 but not always 100%.
  4. Subcutaneous (SC): Similar to IM, the bioavailability of drugs administered subcutaneously is usually high but typically less than 1 due to absorption factors at the injection site.

 

Given this information:

 

  • A (Intravenous = 1) is correct.
  • C (0.75 < IM < 1) is plausible, but like oral administration, the lower limit is not a fixed value.
  • D (0.75 < SC < 1) follows the same reasoning as IM; it's generally true but with a variable lower limit.

 

Other Options:

 

  • B. (0.75 < Oral < 1) is plausible, although the lower limit of 0.75 is arbitrary and not universally applicable as oral bioavailability can vary widely.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most accurate answer, considering the typical bioavailability ranges for these routes, is B. A, C, D. However, it's important to note that specific values (like 0.75) provided for oral, IM, and SC routes are not absolute and can vary depending on the drug and other factors.

questions.text:
A hypertensive patient on medication presents with the lab values as shown below. (INICET MAY 2022)

 

Which of the following drugs should be stopped?
 

K+ :6.5 meg/L

Na+ :137 meg/L

Urea: 42 mg/dL

Creatinine: 3.8 mg/dL
questions.solution:
Ans.  C. Losartan
 

Let's analyze the lab values and determine which medication, if any, should be stopped:

 

  1. Elevated Potassium (K+): A potassium level of 6.5 mEq/L is higher than the normal range (usually around 3.5 to 5.0 mEq/L). High potassium levels, known as hyperkalemia, can be a concern, especially for patients taking certain medications that can affect potassium levels.
  2. Normal Sodium (Na+): A sodium level of 137 mEq/L falls within the normal range. There is no immediate concern regarding sodium levels.
  3. Elevated Urea and Creatinine: Urea and creatinine levels are elevated, indicating impaired kidney function. This is a significant concern, as it may suggest that the kidneys are not effectively filtering waste products from the blood.

 

Considering the elevated potassium level and impaired kidney function (elevated urea and creatinine), it is important to stop any drug that causes hyperkalemia. Among the given drugs, losartan is an Angiotensin Receptor Blocker (ARB), which can lead to hyperkalemia by blocking the action of the RAAS pathway. Since this patient has developed Hyperkalemia, Losartan should be stopped.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Amlodipine: A calcium channel blocker used for hypertension. It does not typically affect potassium levels and does not need to be stopped in this scenario.

 

Option B. Hydrochlorothiazide: A thiazide diuretic used for hypertension. It usually causes hypokalemia (low potassium levels), not hyperkalemia. Therefore, it does not need to be stopped in this case.

 

Option D. Furosemide: A loop diuretic used to treat edema and hypertension. Furosemide usually causes hypokalemia and can actually be used to help lower elevated potassium levels. Hence, it should not be stopped and might even be beneficial in this scenario.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In a hypertensive patient with hyperkalemia and impaired kidney function, Losartan should be stopped due to its potential to exacerbate hyperkalemia. Amlodipine, hydrochlorothiazide, and furosemide do not typically increase potassium levels and do not need to be stopped. In fact, furosemide may help in lowering the elevated potassium levels.

questions.text: Which of the following is the most effective oral drug in smoking cessation?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Varenicline 

 

  • Varenicline is a medication specifically developed to help people quit smoking. It works by partially stimulating α4β2 nicotine receptors in the brain, which can reduce withdrawal symptoms and cravings associated with quitting smoking. At the same time, it blocks nicotine from attaching to these receptors, making smoking less satisfying. This dual action makes varenicline an effective option for smoking cessation.
  • The Other Options listed (B. Cevimeline, C. Muscarine, and D. Atropine) are not typically used for smoking cessation, and their mechanisms of action are not directly related to helping individuals quit smoking.
  • Other drugs used in smoking cessation are bupropion and nicotine replacement therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Cevimeline: This drug is a muscarinic agonist used to treat dry mouth in patients with Sjögren's syndrome. It is not used for smoking cessation and does not have a mechanism that would help in quitting smoking.

 

Option C. Muscarine: This is a naturally occurring compound that acts as an agonist at muscarinic acetylcholine receptors. It is not used in clinical practice for smoking cessation.

 

Option D. Atropine: This is an antimuscarinic agent used to treat bradycardia and for preoperative reduction of saliva. It has no role in smoking cessation.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Varenicline is the most effective oral medication for smoking cessation due to its unique mechanism of partially stimulating and blocking nicotine receptors, thereby reducing cravings and the satisfaction derived from smoking. Other drugs like cevimeline, muscarine, and atropine do not have the same efficacy or mechanism for aiding in smoking cessation.

questions.text: Match the following antiarrhythmic drugs with their mechanism of action:(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 1-a, 2-d, 3-b, 4-c

 

The correct match of antiarrhythmic drugs with their mechanisms of action is as follows:

 

  1. Na+ channel blocker (Class Ia):
    • a. Quinidine: Quinidine is a Na+ channel blocker with additional potassium channel blocking properties, classifying it as a Class Ia antiarrhythmic drug. It slows phase 0 of the action potential, leading to a prolonged QRS duration.
  2. K+ channel blocker (Class III):
    • d. Ibutilide: Ibutilide primarily blocks potassium channels, which prolongs repolarization and action potential duration, making it a Class III antiarrhythmic drug.
  3. Na+ K+ ATPase inhibitor:
    • b. Digoxin: Digoxin inhibits the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, leading to an increase in intracellular calcium and positive inotropic effects, which is useful in heart failure and some arrhythmias.
  4. Beta-blocker (Class II):
    • c. Esmolol: Esmolol is a short-acting beta-blocker that reduces heart rate and myocardial contractility by blocking beta-adrenergic receptors, classifying it as a Class II antiarrhythmic drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Quinidine – Na+ Channel Blocker with additional potassium channel blocking property. (class Ia anti-arrhythmic drugs)
  2. Digoxin – Na+-K+-ATPase inhibitor.
  3. Esmolol – β blocker. Belongs to Class II anti arrhythmics.
  4. Ibutilide – K+ channel blocker. Class III anti arrhythmics.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs increases trabecular outflow?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Netarsudil

 

Netarsudil is used in the treatment of glaucoma, it is a Rho-kinase inhibitor that acts by increasing the trabecular outflow. The other drugs that act by increasing the trabecular outflow are the miotic drugs like Pilocarpine, Physostigmine and Ecothiophate.

 

Other Options:


Option A. Timolol: Is a non-selective Beta blocker which is used in treatment of glaucoma. It acts by reducing the aqueous formation.

 

Option C. Brimonidine: Is a topical alpha-receptor agonist. It acts by increasing the uveoscleral outflow and reduces the aqueous formation

 

Option D. Acetazolamide: Is a carbonic anhydrase inhibitor which reduces aqueous formation

 

Educational Objective:

 

Netarsudil is effective in treating glaucoma by increasing trabecular outflow. This mechanism distinguishes it from other drugs like Timolol, Brimonidine, and Acetazolamide, which primarily reduce aqueous humor production or increase uveoscleral outflow.

choices.text: 5-alpha reductase

questions.text: Finasteride is used to treat male-pattern baldness acts by inhibiting which of the following enzymes?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. 5-alpha reductase

 

5-α Reductase is the enzyme that helps in the conversion of Testosterone into its active form Dihydrotestosterone (DHT). This is implicated in the causation of Androgenetic Alopecia or the male-pattern baldness. Finasteride is the drug that works by inhibiting the 5-α Reductase enzyme within the hair follicle, thereby preventing the male pattern hair loss.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aromatase: Aromatase is the enzyme which converts androgens into estrogens. This enzyme is inhibited by Aromatase inhibitors which are Letrozole, Anastrozole and Exemestane

 

Option B. 17-hydrolase: 17-hydrolase is the enzyme which is involved in Steroid biosynthesis. It is present in Adrenals and Ovaries.

 

Option D. Phosphodiesterase: Phosphodiesterase metabolize cGMP and cAMP. It is inhibited by PDE inhibitors like Theophylline (non-specific), Milrinone (PDE-3) and Sildenafil (PDE-5) etc.
