Educational Objective:

 

Finasteride treats male-pattern baldness by inhibiting the enzyme 5-alpha reductase, which prevents the conversion of testosterone to dihydrotestosterone (DHT), the hormone responsible for hair follicle miniaturization in androgenetic alopecia. This targeted inhibition helps in slowing hair loss and promoting hair regrowth.

choices.text: Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD20
Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD50
Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD20
Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD50

questions.text: Rituximab is a:
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD20

 

  • The suffix Mab implicates that it is a monoclonal antibody.
  • Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody against CD-20 which is expressed on the B-cells.
  • It is used in the treatment of B-cell lymphoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD20: Polyclonal antibodies are produced by multiple clones of B-cells and therefore recognize multiple epitopes. Rituximab is not a polyclonal antibody; it is a monoclonal antibody.

 

Option B. Polyclonal antibody which acts against CD50: This is incorrect because rituximab is not polyclonal and does not target CD50.

 

Option D. Monoclonal antibody which acts against CD50: This is incorrect because rituximab targets CD20, not CD50.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rituximab is a monoclonal antibody that targets the CD20 antigen on B-cells, making it effective in treating B-cell lymphoma, non-Hodgkin lymphoma, and chronic lymphocytic leukemia. The specificity of rituximab for CD20 allows it to selectively destroy B-cells, providing therapeutic benefits in these conditions.

questions.text: New drug application is filed after which phase of clinical trials?(INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. 3 

 

It is after the phase 3 of clinical trials that the drug is finally released in the market after being approved by the CDSCO/FDA. Therefore, a New drug application is filed after phase 3 of clinical trials.

 

The phases of clinical trials are as follows: -


Phase 1 - Done in healthy individuals to assess the maximum tolerable dose, safety and pharmacokinetics of the drug.


Phase 2 - Done in a small number of patients to find out whether the drug actually works or not, in other words to know about the treatment efficacy.


Phase 3 – Done in a large number of patients to compare the new treatment with the current standard of care. It is introduced into the market after this phase.


Phase 4 - Post marketing surveillance to detect the rare or long-term adverse effects, can even result in the treatment being withdrawn from the market.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A New Drug Application (NDA) is filed after the successful completion of Phase 3 clinical trials, where the drug's effectiveness and safety are confirmed in a larger patient population. This phase is critical for regulatory approval and subsequent market release of the drug.

questions.text: A 52-year-old female with diabetes mellitus has experienced a decrease in her HbA1c levels from 7.6 to 6.7 after starting a new oral medication. Laboratory tests show that she has high levels of GIP and GLP-1 and low levels of glucagon. Which of the following oral drugs was most likely administered to this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Alogliptin.

 

Alogliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor, an oral class of drugs used in the treatment of diabetes. DPP-4 inhibitors work by preventing the breakdown of GLP-1, thereby increasing the levels of GLP-1 in the body, which in turn enhances insulin secretion, reduces glucagon secretion, and slows gastric emptying.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Voglibose: Voglibose is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that delays the absorption of carbohydrates in the intestines. It does not directly affect the levels of incretin hormones like GLP-1 and GIP, nor does it significantly influence glucagon levels.

 

Option C. Pramlintide: Pramlintide is an amylin analogue that is used to help control blood sugar levels. It is typically administered by injection and does not significantly increase GLP-1 or GIP levels. It works by slowing gastric emptying and suppressing glucagon secretion, but it does not match the profile described in the question as closely as alogliptin.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: Liraglutide is a GLP-1 agonist, which would indeed lead to increased GLP-1 levels and decreased glucagon levels. However, liraglutide is administered by injection and not orally. This makes it less likely to be the medication described in the scenario, which specifies an oral drug.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Alogliptin, a DPP-4 inhibitor, is the most likely drug responsible for the increase in GLP-1 and GIP levels and the decrease in glucagon levels in this patient. It effectively lowers HbA1c levels and is administered orally, fitting the description provided.

questions.text: A male patient is being treated for a mood disorder. After starting a new medication, he experiences priapism, a prolonged, painful erection. The healthcare provider is considering changing the medication. Which drug is most likely responsible for causing priapism in this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Trazodone

 

Trazodone is an atypical antidepressant that is often used off-label for insomnia. It is known to cause priapism as a rare but serious side effect. Given that the patient has a mood disorder and experienced priapism, trazodone is the most likely culprit.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Venlafaxine: This is a serotonin-norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SNRI) used to treat depression and anxiety disorders. While sexual dysfunction is a potential side effect, it is not commonly associated with priapism.

 

Option C. Bupropion: This is an atypical antidepressant used for depression and smoking cessation. It is not commonly associated with priapism as a side effect.

 

Option D. Mirtazapine: This is another atypical antidepressant used for depression. It also has a low likelihood of causing priapism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trazodone is the most likely antidepressant to cause priapism among the listed options due to its known side effect profile. This serious condition necessitates careful monitoring and potentially switching medications to prevent recurrence.

choices.text: The trial investigated NSCLC treatment using a combination of pembrolizumab and chemotherapy.
The trial focused solely on the use of pembrolizumab for treating NSCLC.
The study explored the efficacy of combining nivolumab and chemotherapy for NSCLC.
The trial looked at nivolumab as a treatment option for NSCLC.

questions.text: An oncologist is discussing with a colleague about the latest evidence-based approaches to treating non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC). The KEYNOTE-189 trial comes up in their conversation. Which of the following accurately describes the focus of the KEYNOTE-189 trial? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. The trial investigated NSCLC treatment using a combination of pembrolizumab and chemotherapy.

 

The KEYNOTE trials are a series of clinical studies investigating the use of pembrolizumab, an immune checkpoint inhibitor, in various types of cancer. Pembrolizumab targets the PD-1 receptor, thereby enabling the immune system to better recognize and attack cancer cells.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. The trial focused solely on the use of pembrolizumab for treating NSCLC: This is incorrect. The KEYNOTE-189 trial investigated pembrolizumab in combination with chemotherapy, not as a monotherapy.

 

Option C. The study explored the efficacy of combining nivolumab and chemotherapy for NSCLC: This is incorrect. The KEYNOTE-189 trial did not involve nivolumab; it focused on pembrolizumab in combination with chemotherapy.

 

Option D. The trial looked at nivolumab as a treatment option for NSCLC: This is incorrect. The KEYNOTE-189 trial was centered on pembrolizumab, not nivolumab.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient undergoing renal transplant management was started on cyclosporine as part of the immunosuppressive regimen. Within a few weeks, the patient begins to show elevated liver enzymes and bilirubin levels. The treating physician suspects drug-induced cholestasis and considers the involvement of a specific cellular transporter. Which cellular transporter is most likely responsible for cyclosporine-induced cholestasis in this patient
questions.solution:
Ans. C. MRP2

 

  • MRP2, also known as Multi-Drug Resistance-associated Protein 2 or ABCC2, is a membrane-bound transporter protein that belongs to the ATP-binding cassette (ABC) family of transporters.
  • This protein is primarily expressed in the liver, particularly in the canalicular membrane of hepatocytes, as well as in the kidneys, intestines, and other tissues.
  • MRP2 functions as an efflux pump, actively transporting a variety of substances out of cells including bile salts, bilirubin, glucuronides, and various drugs and their metabolites.
  • MRP2 plays a critical role in the efflux of bile salts and bilirubin into the bile canaliculus. Mutations or inhibition of MRP2 (by drugs like cyclosporine) can lead to cholestasis, a condition where bile cannot flow from the liver to the duodenum.
  • Dubin-Johnson Syndrome is a genetic disorder resulting from mutations in the MRP2 gene, leading to conjugated hyperbilirubinemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. MDR 1: Multi-Drug Resistance Protein 1 (MDR 1 or P-glycoprotein) is more known for its role in drug resistance, not specifically for cyclosporine-induced cholestasis. While MDR-1 plays a role in drug metabolism and can be inhibited by cyclosporine, it is generally not implicated in the development of drug-induced cholestasis, which is more closely associated with MRP2 inhibition.

 

Option B. BRCA: The Breast Cancer Susceptibility Gene (BRCA) is not related to drug metabolism or cholestasis. It is mainly involved in DNA repair and cancer susceptibility.

 

Option D. OATP1B1: Organic Anion Transporting Polypeptide 1B1 (OATP1B1) is involved in drug uptake into the liver but is not the key player in cyclosporine-induced cholestasis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRP2 (Multi-Drug Resistance-associated Protein 2) is the cellular transporter most likely responsible for cyclosporine-induced cholestasis due to its role in the efflux of bile salts and bilirubin into the bile canaliculus.

questions.text: Which of the following is a new approved drug for Rett syndrome. (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Trofinetide

 

Rett syndrome is an X-linked genetic disorder mostly seen in females. Symptoms include impairments in language and coordination, and repetitive movements. It occurs due to mutation in MECP2 gene.

 

Trofinetide is an analog of glypromate or glycine–proline–glutamate (GPE), a naturally occurring protein in the brain and the N-terminal tripeptide of insulin-like growth factor 1 (IGF-1). GPE exhibits neuroprotective properties: it protects neurons from glutamate-mediated excitotoxicity and oxidative stress.

 

Trofinetide has similar neuroprotective properties and has longer half-life.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Zavegepant: This is a CGRP antagonist approved for the treatment of migraine, not for Rett syndrome.

 

Option C. Sparsentan: This is a dual endothelin antagonist and angiotensin receptor antagonist approved for the treatment of IgA nephropathy, not Rett syndrome.

 

Option D. Elacestrant: This is a selective estrogen receptor downregulator approved as an oral treatment for breast cancer, not Rett syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Trofinetide is a newly approved drug for Rett syndrome, exhibiting neuroprotective properties similar to those of glypromate (GPE), and is beneficial for treating the symptoms of this genetic disorder.

questions.text: An individual with type 2 diabetes mellitus was prescribed a medication that lowered their HbA1C levels from 7.6 to 6.7. Subsequently, the person began experiencing discomfort characterized by itching in the vulvovaginal region. What is the probable medication that was initiated for this individual? (INICET May 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Canagliflozin

 

The patient complaining of itching in genital region after consuming a drug to lower down HbA1C levels is likely pointing to urogenital infection, which is a side effect associated with Canagliflozin (SGLT2 inhibitor).

 

SGLT-2 INHIBITORS

 

  • Glucose is freely filtered by glomerulus but the clearance of glucose in urine is negligible.
  • Because the reabsorption takes place in proximal tubule by sodium glucose transporter (SGLT-2)
  • SGLT-2 inhibitors stop the reabsorption of glucose in PT resulting in glucosuria.
  • Most common side effect of SGLT-2 Inhibitors is Urinary Tract infections (urosepsis) and genital Tract infections. (e.g., Fournier’s gangrene)
  • If gliflozins are taken by type 1 diabetes patients, it controls blood sugar level and makes it normal and then if the patients stop taking insulin, it will result in Ketoacidosis (as type 1 diabetes is characterized by complete deficiency of insulin)
  • SLGT-2 inhibitors provide cardiovascular benefits. These are approved for treatment of CHF.
  • Drugs are.
    • Canagliflozin
    • Dapagliflozin
    • Empagliflozin
    • Ertugliflozin

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Acarbose: This is an alpha-glucosidase inhibitor that primarily acts in the intestine to slow down the breakdown of complex carbohydrates. It is not usually associated with vulvovaginal itching.

 

Option C. Linagliptin: A DPP-4 inhibitor, Linagliptin is not typically associated with vulvovaginal itching or infections.

 

Option D. Liraglutide: This GLP-1 agonist is more commonly associated with gastrointestinal side effects rather than vulvovaginal itching.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Canagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that lowers blood sugar by causing more glucose to be excreted in the urine. It is known for causing genitourinary infections, including vulvovaginal candidiasis, which can result in symptoms like itching and discomfort.

questions.text: Following a hysterectomy, the patient received morphine for pain management both during the post-operative period and while in the ward. The current symptoms include respiratory depression and constricted (pinpoint) pupils. What would be the recommended medication for this patient? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Naloxone

 

  • The given clinical scenario is suggestive of opioid poisoning due to morphine, for which IV Naloxone can be administered.
  • In Morphine poisoning, the patient usually present in comatose state with low BP and heart rate as -receptor causes depression of brain including cardiovascular center.

 

SYMPTOMS OF OPIOID POISONING

 

  • Coma, respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils
  • Hypotension, bradycardia
  • Bradypnea
  • Hypothermia

 

ANTAGONISTS

 

  • Naloxone - Short acting, given iv
  • Naltrexone - Long acting, given Orally
  • DOC for acute opioid poisoning Naloxone
  • DOC for maintenance in opioid poisoning Naltrexone
    • Naloxone is added to oral opioids to reduce addictive potential.
    • Naltrexone is used to decrease craving in alcoholics.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Pethidine/Meperidine is a receptor agonist.

 

Option B. Atropine is an anticholinergic drug. Used in cases of organophosphate poisoning.

 

Option D. Buprenorphine is a partial receptor agonist and an antagonist at delta and kappa receptor. It has ceiling Effect on respiratory depression.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Naloxone is the drug of choice for treating acute opioid overdose, characterized by symptoms such as respiratory depression, pinpoint pupils, and coma. It acts rapidly to reverse the effects of opioids by competitively inhibiting their action at opioid receptors.

questions.text: A young boy recently visited a temple with his grandmother. Upon returning, he has been crying inconsolably, presenting with cold extremities and a blood pressure of 170/100 mm Hg. What is the most appropriate course of treatment for his condition? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Prazosin

 

The patient's symptoms are suggestive of scorpion sting, characterized by symptoms of vasoconstriction like hypertension and cold extremities. Prazosin, an alpha-1 blocker is drug of choice for treatment of scorpion sting.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Prednisolone: Prednisolone is a corticosteroid that reduces inflammation and suppresses the immune response. However, it is not typically used to manage scorpion stings, as it does not address the acute hypertensive crisis and autonomic storm caused by the sting.

 

Option C. Adrenaline: Adrenaline (epinephrine) is a catecholamine that increases heart rate and blood pressure. It would likely exacerbate the hypertension and vasoconstriction already present in the patient, making it an inappropriate treatment choice for scorpion sting.

 

Option D. Anti-snake venom: Anti-snake venom is used to neutralize the effects of snake bites. The symptoms described do not align with a snake bite but rather with a scorpion sting, making this treatment inappropriate.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The most appropriate treatment for a scorpion sting, which presents with severe pain, hypertension, and cold extremities, is prazosin. It effectively counters the effects of excessive catecholamine release by blocking alpha-1 adrenergic receptors, thereby reducing vasoconstriction and lowering blood pressure.

choices.text: It is approved for treatment of absent seizures
Fine tremors can be noted within therapeutic range

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding lithium is correct? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Fine tremors can be noted within therapeutic range

 

Lithium is a commonly used medication for the treatment of bipolar disorder, but it can cause fine tremors within the therapeutic range. The tremors are generally mild and not a significant side effect for most patients, but in some cases, they can be bothersome.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is approved for treatment of absent seizures: This is incorrect. Lithium is not used for the treatment of absent seizures. It is primarily used in the management of bipolar disorder and sometimes for treatment-resistant depression.

 

Option C. It does not cause teratogenicity: This is incorrect. Lithium can cause teratogenic effects, particularly if used during the first trimester of pregnancy. It is associated with an increased risk of cardiac anomalies, such as Ebstein's anomaly.

 

Option D. It is not absorbed orally: This is incorrect. Lithium is well absorbed orally and reaches peak plasma concentrations within a few hours of ingestion.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lithium, a medication commonly used for bipolar disorder, can cause fine tremors within the therapeutic range. It is well absorbed orally and has teratogenic potential, making it important to use with caution in pregnant women.

questions.text: Which of the following is a rare but serious adverse effect of clozapine (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Agranulocytosis.

 

Agranulocytosis is a rare but serious adverse effect of clozapine. Agranulocytosis is a condition characterized by a dangerously low level of neutrophils (a type of white blood cell) in the blood. Neutrophils are crucial for fighting infection, so their reduction significantly increases the risk of serious infections. Patients on clozapine are closely monitored with regular blood tests to detect this condition early.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Akathisia: This is a condition characterized by a feeling of inner restlessness and an inability to stay still. It is a common side effect of typical antipsychotics but it is unlikely to be seen with clozapine.

 

Option C. Respiratory depression: While antipsychotics can have sedating effects, respiratory depression is not commonly associated with clozapine.

 

Option D. Hyperthermia: This is not typically associated with clozapine. Hyperthermia can occur with neuroleptic malignant syndrome (NMS), a rare but serious side effect of typical antipsychotics in general. It is not associated with the use of clozapine.


Educational Objective:

 

Agranulocytosis is a rare but serious adverse effect of clozapine, requiring regular monitoring of white blood cell counts to ensure early detection and prevention of serious infections.

questions.text: A 45-year-old patient with a known allergy to penicillin presents with a enterococcal endocarditis. The physician needs to prescribe an antibiotic but wants to ensure it is safe for a patient with a penicillin allergy. The patient has had previous allergic reactions to penicillin, including rash and swelling. Which of the following drugs can be used safely in a patient allergic to penicillin?
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vancomycin

 

  • The clinical scenario involves a 45-year-old patient with enterococcal endocarditis and a known allergy to penicillin, presenting with previous allergic reactions including rash and swelling. 
  • The physician needs to choose an antibiotic that is safe for a patient with a penicillin allergy as well as effective for enterococcal endocarditis. Let's review the options:
  • Vancomycin is a glycopeptide antibiotic that is not related to penicillin. 
  • It is safe for patients with penicillin allergies and is commonly used to treat gram-positive infections, including those caused by enterococci.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Aztreonam: Aztreonam is a monobactam antibiotic that is generally considered safe for patients with penicillin allergies because it does not share the beta-lactam ring structure of penicillins, which is typically responsible for allergic reactions. However, aztreonam is effective only against gram negative bacteria and is not suitable for enterococcal infections which is a gram positive bacteria.

 

Option C. Ceftriaxone: Ceftriaxone is a third-generation cephalosporin. Although cephalosporins have a beta-lactam ring similar to penicillins, the rate of cross-reactivity is relatively low, especially with third-generation cephalosporins. However, caution is advised in patients with a history of severe penicillin allergy.

 

Option D. Piperacillin: Piperacillin is a penicillin derivative and should be avoided in patients with penicillin allergies due to the high risk of cross-reactivity and potential for severe allergic reactions.

 

Conclusion

 

The safest options for a patient with a penicillin allergy are:

 

Aztreonam (Option a)

 

Vancomycin (Option b)

 

Given the specific need to avoid penicillin and its derivatives and to treat gram positive (enterococcal) infections, Vancomycin is a safe and effective choice for treating enterococcal endocarditis in this patient. Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

b. Vancomycin

questions.text: Which of the following diuretic is correctly matched with its site of action (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - Proximal tubule

 

Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors - These act in the proximal tubule. Acetazolamide is a commonly used carbonic anhydrase inhibitor.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Osmotic diuretics- Collecting duct: These work primarily in the proximal tubule and the descending limb of the loop of Henle, not the collecting duct. Mannitol is a common example.

 

Option C. Thiazides-Loop of Henle: These primarily act on the distal convoluted tubule. Hydrochlorothiazide is a typical example.

 

Option D. Aldosterone antagonists- early Distal tubules: These work in the collecting ducts and late distal tubules. Spironolactone is a well-known aldosterone antagonist.

questions.text: Most potent natural estrogen is (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Estradiol

 

Estradiol (E2) is the most potent natural estrogen. It is the primary estrogen produced by the ovaries during the reproductive years and plays a crucial role in regulating the menstrual cycle and reproductive system.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Conjugated estrogen: Conjugated estrogen like Ethinyl estradiol is a synthetic estrogen commonly used in oral contraceptives. It is not a natural estrogen.

 

Option B. Estrone: Estrone (E1) is one of the three naturally occurring estrogens. It is less potent than estradiol. Estrone is primarily produced in adipose tissue and is the predominant estrogen after menopause.

 

Option D. Estriol: Estriol (E3) is the weakest of the three natural estrogens. It is primarily produced during pregnancy by the placenta. Estriol has much lower estrogenic activity compared to estradiol and estrone.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, estradiol is the most potent natural estrogen and plays a significant role in the female reproductive system during the reproductive years.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presented with fever, cough and tenacious white sputum. Which of the following should be used for treatment? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Syrup bromhexine

 

Bromhexine is a mucolytic agent that helps to thin and loosen mucus, making it easier to expectorate. This is particularly useful for patients with a productive cough and tenacious sputum, as it facilitates the clearance of mucus from the airways.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Syrup Dextromethorphan with bromhexine: Dextromethorphan is a cough suppressant, and bromhexine is a mucolytic. While bromhexine can help thin the mucus, dextromethorphan is not recommended for productive coughs as it suppresses the cough reflex, potentially leading to mucus retention.

 

Option B. Syrup Codeine: Codeine is an opioid cough suppressant. Like dextromethorphan, it is not suitable for productive coughs as it suppresses the cough reflex, which can lead to mucus accumulation in the airways.

 

Option C. Syrup Dextromethorphan: Dextromethorphan is a cough suppressant that is not appropriate for productive coughs, as it can prevent the clearing of mucus from the respiratory tract.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, syrup bromhexine is the most appropriate choice for treating a patient with fever, cough, and tenacious white sputum, as it helps to thin and loosen the mucus, making it easier to clear from the respiratory tract.

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient presents with progressive dyspnoea at rest and on exertion (e.g., climbing stairs). The patient also has a history of heart failure. Laboratory tests show a fasting plasma glucose of 136 mg/dL, haemoglobin (Hb) of 13 g%, and HbA1c of 7.8%, indicating poorly controlled type 2 diabetes mellitus. The physician needs to select an appropriate antidiabetic medication considering the patient's symptoms and medical condition. Which is the preferred antidiabetic drug in this patient?(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Dapagliflozin

 

  • Dapagliflozin is an SGLT2 inhibitor that promotes glucose excretion through the urine. It has been shown to provide significant benefits in patients with type 2 diabetes and heart failure, including reducing the risk of hospitalization for heart failure and cardiovascular death. Given the patient's history of heart failure, dapagliflozin is a preferred choice due to its cardiovascular benefits.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Glimepiride: Glimepiride is a sulfonylurea that increases insulin secretion. It is associated with a risk of hypoglycemia and weight gain, which might not be ideal for this patient considering the need to manage cardiovascular risk factors and avoid potential hypoglycemic episodes.

 

Option C. Metformin: Metformin is a first-line treatment for type 2 diabetes due to its efficacy and safety profile. However, in this case, given the patient's history of heart failure, dapagliflozin may provide additional cardiovascular benefits that make it a more suitable choice.

 

Option D. Sitagliptin: Sitagliptin is a DPP-4 inhibitor that helps improve blood glucose control with a low risk of hypoglycemia and is weight neutral. While it is effective, it does not have the same cardiovascular benefits as dapagliflozin in patients with heart failure.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, dapagliflozin is the preferred antidiabetic drug for this patient due to its proven benefits in reducing heart failure-related outcomes, making it particularly suitable for a patient with a history of heart failure and poorly controlled diabetes.

questions.text: Drug resistance is most commonly seen with which of the following infections? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Gonorrhea

 

  • Gonorrhea is caused by the bacterium Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It is notorious for developing resistance to multiple classes of antibiotics, including penicillins, tetracyclines, fluoroquinolones, and most recently, some strains have shown reduced susceptibility to cephalosporins and azithromycin. Drug-resistant gonorrhea is a significant public health challenge, and the CDC recommends dual therapy with ceftriaxone and azithromycin to address this issue.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Chancroid: Chancroid is caused by the bacterium Haemophilus ducreyi. While there have been cases of antibiotic resistance, it is not as prevalent or significant as in gonorrhea.

 

Option B. Donovanosis: Donovanosis (granuloma inguinale) is caused by Klebsiella granulomatis. It is relatively rare, and drug resistance has not been a major issue in its treatment.

 

Option C. Syphilis: Syphilis is caused by the bacterium Treponema pallidum. While there are concerns about resistance to some antibiotics, such as macrolides, penicillin remains highly effective, and resistance is not as significant a problem as in gonorrhea.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, gonorrhea is the infection most commonly associated with drug resistance, making it a critical concern in the treatment of STIs.

questions.text: Inhalational anaesthetic agent of choice in children is(INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sevoflurane

 

  • Sevoflurane is the inhalational anesthetic agent of choice in children. It has a rapid onset and offset, a pleasant smell, and causes minimal airway irritation, making it ideal for inhalational induction in pediatric patients. It also has a relatively low blood-gas partition coefficient, leading to quick recovery times.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Desflurane: Desflurane is another potent inhalational anesthetic with a very low blood-gas partition coefficient, resulting in rapid induction and emergence from anesthesia. However, it can cause airway irritation and coughing, making it less suitable for children, particularly for inhalational induction.

 

Option C. Nitrous oxide: Nitrous oxide is commonly used as an adjunct to other anesthetic agents due to its analgesic properties and rapid onset. However, it is not used as the sole agent for induction of anesthesia because it is not potent enough to achieve surgical anesthesia on its own.

 

Option D. Isoflurane: Isoflurane is a potent inhalational anesthetic but has a pungent odor and can cause airway irritation. It is less commonly used for inhalational induction in children due to these properties.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, sevoflurane is preferred for pediatric anesthesia due to its favorable profile, including rapid onset and recovery, minimal airway irritation, and a pleasant smell, making it well-tolerated by children.

questions.text: Which of the following is a PCSK-9 inhibtior? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Evolocumab

 

  • Evolocumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits proprotein convertase subtilisin/kexin type 9 (PCSK-9). By inhibiting PCSK-9, evolocumab increases the number of low-density lipoprotein (LDL) receptors available on the surface of liver cells, thereby reducing LDL cholesterol levels in the blood. It is used for the treatment of hypercholesterolemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ezetimibe: Ezetimibe is a cholesterol absorption inhibitor that works by reducing the absorption of cholesterol in the small intestine. It is used to lower LDL cholesterol levels but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option C. Evinacumab: Evinacumab is a monoclonal antibody that inhibits angiopoietin-like protein 3 (ANGPTL3), which reduces levels of triglycerides, LDL cholesterol, and other lipids. It is used for treating homozygous familial hypercholesterolemia but is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Option D. Everolimus: Everolimus is an mTOR inhibitor used primarily as an immunosuppressant in transplant patients and in certain types of cancer. It is not related to cholesterol metabolism and is not a PCSK-9 inhibitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, evolocumab is the correct answer as it is a PCSK-9 inhibitor used to lower LDL cholesterol levels.

choices.text: Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is un-competitive inhibitor
Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor
Drug A is non-competitive inhibitor and drug B is competitive inhibitor
Drug A is un-competitive inhibitor and drug B is competitive inhibitor

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding the drugs shown in graph A and graph B is correct. (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans B) Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor

 

To determine the correct answer, let's analyze the Lineweaver-Burk plots and the types of enzyme inhibition they represent:

 

For non-competitive inhibitors, the lines intersect at the x-axis. This type of inhibitor decreases VmaxVmax without affecting KmKm.

 

Option A. Competitive Inhibition: On a Lineweaver-Burk plot, competitive inhibitors intersect with the no-inhibitor line at the y-axis. This is because competitive inhibitors increase the apparent KmKm (Michaelis constant) without affecting VmaxVmax (maximum velocity).

 

Option C. Uncompetitive Inhibition: Uncompetitive inhibitors result in parallel lines on the Lineweaver-Burk plot. They decrease both VmaxVmax and KmKm proportionally. 

 

Given the descriptions of the graphs:

 

  • Graph A: The lines meet at the y-axis, indicating competitive inhibition.
  • Graph B: The lines start from the same point on the x-axis, indicating non-competitive inhibition.

 

Therefore, the correct answer is:

 

B. Drug A is competitive inhibitor and drug B is non-competitive inhibitor

questions.text: Cannabinoids are not approved for treatment of (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Rett syndrome

 

  • Cannabinoids, including cannabidiol (CBD), are not currently approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome. 
  • Rett syndrome is a rare genetic neurological disorder, and while there is ongoing research into potential treatments, cannabinoids are not among the approved therapies for this condition.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Dravet Syndrome: Cannabidiol (CBD) is approved for the treatment of Dravet Syndrome, a severe form of epilepsy. It is used to reduce the frequency of seizures in patients with this condition.

 

Option B. Tuberous sclerosis: Cannabidiol (CBD) is also approved for the treatment of seizures associated with Tuberous Sclerosis Complex (TSC). It has been shown to reduce seizure frequency in patients with TSC.

 

Option D. Lennox Gastaut syndrome: Cannabidiol (CBD) is approved for the treatment of Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome, another severe form of epilepsy. It is used to help reduce the frequency of seizures in patients with this syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, cannabinoids, specifically cannabidiol (CBD), are not approved for the treatment of Rett syndrome, whereas they are approved for use in Dravet Syndrome, Tuberous Sclerosis, and Lennox-Gastaut Syndrome.

choices.text: It should not be given with pyrazinamide
It should be taken empty stomach
It is given as a loading dose

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient with a history of chronic pulmonary aspergillosis is being treated with voriconazole. He has been on the medication for two weeks and comes to the clinic for a follow-up. During the visit, he asks about the specific guidelines and considerations for taking voriconazole to ensure its effectiveness and safety. Which of the following statements is true about voriconazole? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) It is given as a loading dose
 

Voriconazole requires a loading dose to rapidly achieve therapeutic levels in the body. This is a crucial aspect of its administration, especially in acute settings where rapid antifungal activity is needed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It should not be given with pyrazinamide: There is no significant interaction between voriconazole and pyrazinamide. Voriconazole does interact with many other medications due to its effect on cytochrome P450 enzymes, but pyrazinamide is not one of the primary concerns.

 

Option B. It should be taken empty stomach: Voriconazole can be taken either with or without food, but it is generally recommended to take it one hour before or one hour after a meal to ensure optimal absorption. While this is important, it is not the most critical consideration compared to therapeutic drug monitoring.

 

Option D. It requires therapeutic drug monitoring: While therapeutic drug monitoring can be important for voriconazole, especially in certain patient populations, it is not as universally mandated or emphasized as the initial loading dose regimen in standard treatment protocols.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, the statement that voriconazole "is given as a loading dose" is the most universally applicable and critical aspect of its administration, especially for ensuring rapid therapeutic levels in treating fungal infections.

questions.text: All of the following drugs act as HER-1 inhibitors except (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Pertuzumab

 

  • Pertuzumab is a monoclonal antibody that targets HER-2 (Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 2), not HER-1. 
  • It is used primarily in the treatment of HER-2 positive breast cancer.
  • HER-1 (Human Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor 1) is also known as EGFR (Epidermal Growth Factor Receptor). 
  • Several monoclonal antibodies target EGFR, while others target different members of the HER family, such as HER-2.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Cetuximab: Cetuximab is an EGFR (HER-1) inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of certain types of colorectal cancer and head and neck cancer.

 

Option B. Necitumumab: Necitumumab is also an EGFR (HER-1) inhibitor, used in the treatment of metastatic squamous non-small cell lung cancer.

 

Option D. Panitumumab: Panitumumab is an EGFR (HER-1) inhibitor, used in the treatment of metastatic colorectal cancer.

 

Given this information, the drug that does not act as a HER-1 inhibitor is: 
c. Pertuzumab

questions.text: A 60-year-old male patient underwent surgery under general anaesthesia. Rocuronium was used as a muscle relaxant during the procedure. After the surgery, the patient has not regained muscle function, indicating prolonged muscle paralysis. The medical team needs to reverse the effects of rocuronium quickly to ensure patient safety and recovery. Which of the following can result in the fastest reversal? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Sugammadex

 

  • Sugammadex is a specific reversal agent for aminosteroid neuromuscular blocking agents such as rocuronium and vecuronium. It works by encapsulating the rocuronium molecules, rendering them inactive, and thus rapidly reversing the neuromuscular blockade. Sugammadex provides the fastest and most effective reversal of rocuronium-induced paralysis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Neostigmine: Neostigmine is an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor that increases the levels of acetylcholine at the neuromuscular junction, competing with rocuronium. While effective, it is slower and less specific than sugammadex and can have more side effects.

 

Option C. Edrophonium: Edrophonium is also an acetylcholinesterase inhibitor but is less commonly used compared to neostigmine for reversing neuromuscular blockade. It is generally faster than neostigmine but still not as rapid or effective as sugammadex for rocuronium reversal.

 

Option D. Atropine: Atropine is not used for reversing neuromuscular blockade. It is an anticholinergic agent primarily used to counteract the muscarinic side effects of acetylcholinesterase inhibitors like neostigmine and edrophonium, such as bradycardia. It does not reverse muscle paralysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In summary, sugammadex is the most effective and fastest-acting agent for reversing the effects of rocuronium, making it the best choice in this clinical scenario.

choices.text: Dexamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 2 doses
Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 12 hourly 2 doses
Betamethasone 12 mg 24 hourly 4 doses

questions.text: A 28-year-old pregnant woman at 32 weeks of gestation presents to the obstetric clinic with signs of preterm labor. The medical team decides to administer corticosteroids to promote fetal lung maturation and reduce the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome. Choose the correct option that should be used for fetal lung maturation: (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses

 

For promoting fetal lung maturation in cases of threatened preterm labor, corticosteroids are administered to enhance the production of surfactant, which helps in reducing the risk of neonatal respiratory distress syndrome.

 

The commonly recommended regimens are:

 

  • Betamethasone: 12 mg intramuscularly every 24 hours for 2 doses.
  • Dexamethasone: 6 mg intramuscularly every 12 hours for 4 doses.

 

Given these recommendations, the correct options is:

 

B. Dexamethasone 6 mg 12 hourly 4 doses

questions.text:
Which of the following drug is/are used for cyanide poisoning?

 

  1. Amyl nitrite
  2. Sodium nitrite
  3. Sodium thiosulfate
  4. Glyceryl trinitrate
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 1, 2 and 3

 

For cyanide poisoning, the following treatments are commonly used:

 

1. Amyl nitrite: This is an inhalant that induces methemoglobinemia, which binds cyanide ions and forms cyanmethemoglobin, helping to detoxify cyanide.

 

2 Sodium nitrite: This intravenous agent also induces methemoglobinemia, which helps to bind and neutralize cyanide.

 

3. Sodium thiosulfate: This acts as a sulfur donor, converting cyanide to the less toxic thiocyanate, which is excreted by the kidneys.

 

4. Glyceryl trinitrate (commonly known as nitroglycerin) is not typically used for cyanide poisoning.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Based on the options provided, the correct combination of drugs used for cyanide poisoning is: 1, 2, and 3

 

Therefore, the correct answer is: C. 1, 2, and 3

questions.text:
Which of the following is a suicide inhibitor?  (INICET May 2024)

 

  1. Nor-ethindrone
  2. Ritonavir
  3. Spironolactone
  4. Benzbromarone
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1, 2 and 3

 

A suicide inhibitor (also known as a mechanism-based inhibitor) is a type of enzyme inhibitor that binds to an enzyme and undergoes a catalytic reaction, leading to the formation of an irreversible complex. During this reaction, the inhibitor is converted into a reactive form by the enzyme itself, which then covalently binds to the enzyme, permanently inactivating it. In essence, the enzyme commits suicide by converting the inhibitor into a form that irreversibly binds to it, thereby blocking the enzyme's activity permanently.

 

Among the given options, nor-ethindrone, ritonavir and spironolactone are suicide inhibitors whereas benzbromarone is not. 

 

  1. Nor-ethindrone: Nor-ethindrone is a synthetic progestin that is commonly used in hormonal contraceptives. It is also classified as a suicide inhibitor due to its irreversible binding to its target enzyme, leading to permanent inhibition of enzyme activity.
  2. Ritonavir: Ritonavir is an HIV protease inhibitor that acts as a suicide inhibitor. It binds irreversibly to the HIV protease enzyme, permanently inactivating it.
  3. Spironolactone: Spironolactone is a potassium-sparing diuretic and aldosterone antagonist. It is also categorized as a suicide inhibitor because it irreversibly inhibits the 17-hydroxylase enzyme involved in steroid synthesis.
  4. Benzbromarone: Benzbromarone is a uricosuric drug used to treat gout by increasing the renal excretion of uric acid. However, it is not classified as a suicide inhibitor. While it has therapeutic uses, it does not act by irreversibly inactivating enzymes like suicide inhibitors do.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Suicide inhibitors, also known as mechanism-based inhibitors, irreversibly bind to and permanently inactivate their target enzymes. This type of inhibition is significant because the enzyme activity cannot be restored unless new enzymes are synthesized by the body.

 

Mnemonic to Remember Important Suicide Inhibitors:

 

Every Nurse Sees The Clot Results Promptly

 

  • E: Ethinyl estradiol
  • N: Norethindrone
  • S: Spironolactone
  • T: Ticlopidine
  • C: Clopidogrel
  • R: Ritonavir
  • P: Propylthiouracil

choices.text: Enoxaparin
Lepirudin
Fondaparinux
Dabigatran

questions.text: Which of the following anticoagulant requires coagulation profile monitoring? (INICET May 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Lepirudin

 

  • Lepirudin is a direct thrombin inhibitor that typically requires regular monitoring of anticoagulant effect via activated partial thromboplastin time (aPTT).
  • Enoxaparin (a low molecular weight heparin), Fondaparinux (a synthetic pentasaccharide), and Dabigatran (a direct thrombin inhibitor) generally do not require regular monitoring in most patients, although there may be specific clinical situations where monitoring is needed.
